Under President Trump, our economy is soaring, and I was reassured to hear that it will continue on this upward trend. Catch up more on my week by clicking here or the photo below.     To watch my full questioning of Chairman Powell, click here or the photo below.      I sat down with the U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue to discuss the economic challenges facing the hardwood lumber industry. This industry supports 685,000 jobs in our nation, and I was honored to be joined by several of my colleagues to express our concern and support for this hardworking industry. Kustoff.House.Gov    Around Washington and West Tennessee Here's a close look at a few of the highlights from my week:   Thank you to Craig Wright, Senior Vice President of Lipscomb & Pitts Insurance, LLC with The Council of Insurance Agents & Brokers for meeting with me this week. I appreciate you stopping by!    It was great to speak with members of Habitat for Humanity of Greater Memphis up in Washington.     Thank you to Scottie DeLashmit, President of Tennessee State FOP, for meeting with me. Our law enforcement must always be kept a top priority, and I appreciated learning how I can continue to support your work.    I enjoyed sitting down with Tennessee Treasurer David Lillard with the Tennessee Treasury Department. I look forward to continue working closely with you to ensure we tackle issues at every level that are important to Tennesseans.    I was honored to receive the True Blue Award from FRC Action President Tony Perkins for earning a 100% voting record for pro-life and pro-family issues. I will always continue to defend and fight for these important West Tennessee values!    Thank you to Kevin Conway, Vice President of Southern Towing Company for stopping by my office to update me on your work with the Waterways Council. I look forward to our continued conversations.    I enjoyed sitting down with Donald Taylor with the Germantown Police Department and Jamison Peevyhouse- National Emergency Number Association Past President and TECB Training Coordinator to discuss their work with the Tennessee Emergency Communication Board. Thank you for stopping by!       Keep in Touch As always, I am committed to working for you and the Eighth District of Tennessee.  My staff and I are always available to answer questions you may have and address any concerns about what is happening here in Washington.  Please feel free to send me an email by  or visiting my website at Kustoff.House.Gov.   To opt-in to my eNewsletter, click here. It has been a busy two weeks in Washington! I appreciate you taking the time to read my E-Newsletter to stay up-to-date on everything happening in the House of Representatives and back in the district.               President Trump Delivers State of the Union Address   Last week, President Trump laid out a bold vision forward for our country and highlighted the numerous successes of his administration. Our nation has truly experienced a blue-collar boom, with strong year-over-year wage growth and record low unemployment.                             Vice President Pence Visits Lancaster!  It was great to join Vice President Mike Pence for a community leaders roundtable in Lancaster and to hear directly from the people their thoughts about what is happening in Washington. Thanks for the lift back to Washington, aboard Air Force 2!                                       National Prayer Breakfast  It was great to join so many for the National Prayer Breakfast last week. I had the honor of being joined by Pastor Matt Mylin and his wife Kelly, who lead the congregation at the Worship Center in Leola, PA. The morning featured an uplifting message from keynote speaker Arthur Brooks.                                                    From the Floor    This past week, I had the opportunity to speak from the floor of the House to honor two community leaders and to oppose legislation which would harm American workers.  I spoke out against the PRO Act, which is a massive giveaway to union special interests and would have drastically changed the balance of labor laws in favor of unions and against American workers. Click here to watch my remarks on the PRO Act. Additionally, I spoke on the House floor to honor the life of Mr. Robert Aichele, a community leader in Lancaster County, who passed away at the age of 92 last week. Click here to watch my comments honoring the memory of Mr. Aichele.  I also spoke on the House floor to give thanks to Dr. William Griscom, who has recently retired after serving as President of Thaddeus Stevens College of Technology for 23 years. Thousands of lives across south central Pennsylvania have been put on the path to success because of his leadership. Click here to watch my remarks thanking Dr. William Griscom.                              $5 Million Saved for PA-11 Constituents  It was an honor to be able to announce earlier this week, that my office has saved over $5 million for constituents of Pennsylvania’s 11th Congressional District. Since taking office in 2017, my office has closed over 4,000 cases to assist individuals with difficulty they may be experiencing with federal agencies. Click here to learn more about this great milestone!  And click here, if my office can assist you with an issue you’re experiencing with the federal government!                                             Visits to Washington!  It was great to be visited by John Fiorill in my Washington, DC office this week. John is the Second Vice President of the Pennsylvania Fraternal Order of Police, and the former Chief of the Southern Regional Police Department. Thanks for visiting!                                                      Here’s Lloyd  Since I’ve taken office, I’ve held nearly 300 meetings with constituents and nearly 200 visits all across our district including schools, non-profit organizations and small businesses. Keep up to date by following my on Facebook, Twitter and visit “Here’s Lloyd” – a diary of all my visits across PA-11.  If you’d like to invite me to your school, business or community organization, please contact me at: Request a meeting.                                          Follow Me On Social Media           Thank you for subscribing to my newsletter! You can stay up-to-date on what I'm doing in Washington and Pennsylvania by following me on Twitter and Facebook.  Sincerely,  Lloyd Smucker         Washington, DC 127 Cannon HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2411 Lancaster Office 51 S. I also announced $4.5 million worth of funding to modernize and expand outdated locks and dams on the Upper Mississippi and Illinois Rivers.    Congresswoman Bustos signing legislation to create the Rural Health Liaison.  Health care is the number one issue I hear about from folks back home and in rural communities, access to care can present unique challenges. That’s why I was proud that on Friday the USDA appointed the first-ever Rural Health Liaison after I passed legislation to create the role. It’s crucial we ensure small towns across the Heartland have access to 21st Century health care and that’s what this position will help do. I remain committed to lowering health care costs and improving access, and I look forward to working with our first Rural Health Liaison. You can learn more here.  Then, I joined Senators Durbin and Duckworth to announce $4.5 million worth of funding to improve our locks and dams along the Upper Mississippi and Illinois Rivers. Our inland waterways are responsible for moving more than 600 million tons of goods each year, including agricultural products, but outdated locks and dams could bring this local economic driver to a standstill. This funding will help increase our region’s competitive edge, promote efficiency and support our local economy. Read more about it here.  Finally, I was proud to vote in favor of women’s equality when I helped pass a bipartisan resolution to remove the arbitrary deadline Congress previously set to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. With this vote, we take another step forward to guarantee fundamental rights for all and place the ERA on a path to becoming a part of our Constitution.  Until next time, Cheri                                     Please don't reply to this email. If you have any questions, comments, or would like to contact Cheri, please visit the . Bost                  The Bost Bulletin Friend,  As we celebrate Presidents' Day tomorrow, it's important to note the impact each president has had on our nation's history, including Illinois' own Abraham Lincoln. His dedication to freedom is a shining example of the values our country represents. Here's what I've been up to this week.   Protecting Our Children in Schools Having the Securing Our Schools Act, a bill I introduced, signed into law by the President is one of my proudest achievements while serving in Congress. This law created the School Violence Prevention Program (SVPP) to provide law enforcement with the appropriate tools and technology they need to make classrooms safer. Starting this week, the SVPP is accepting applications through April 8, 2020 for this year’s round of grant funding. For more information, please visit here. As a former first responder, I encourage local government leaders, school administrators, and law enforcement to apply ASAP!  Safeguarding Veteran Votes Ensuring Americans have a say in who leads our government is a right our veterans overseas fight for every day. Too often, however, our men and women serving across the world are unable to have their absentee ballots arrive to the States on time for the collection deadline.This is completely unacceptable, which is why I am proud to tell you that I have cosponsored the Counting All Military Votes Act to improve voting accessibility for American active duty service members. Our military men and women overseas are committed to keeping American diplomats and citizens safe and deserve peace of mind knowing that their ballot will be counted in a timely manner.     Empowering the Postal Service Since its creation in 1775, the USPS has remained one of the most reliable government agencies. In fact, it is one of the few explicitly mentioned in the United States Constitution. Today, the USPS employs over 600,000 workers and continues to be an integral function of our government and economy. However, due to a mandate passed over a decade ago, the USPS is obligated to pre-fund its future pensions, losing the agency millions of dollars every year. I'm proud to tell you that legislation I cosponsored, the USPS Fairness Act, passed the House last week. This bill will make sure that employees within the USPS will receive the same retiree health funding benefits that apply to all other federal agencies and allow the USPS to invest in itself for the first time in years.  Prior to its passage, I spoke on the House Floor in support of this legislation. To hear my remarks, please click the link below.     Sending Valentines for Veterans On Thursday, I joined my colleagues in writing Valentine's Day messages to be sent to veterans living in the Washington, D.C. area. Veterans selflessly signed up to defend the freedoms of our great country without asking for anything in return. As a Marine and father of a Marine, I was honored to take part in this small gesture of appreciation for those who have served our nation.    Protecting Correctional Officers Our district is home to United States Penitentiary Marion, but like many facilities, it is not staffed at the proper level. Studies show that understaffed facilities have more assaults against workers and more inmate suicides. Recently, I led a letter asking the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) to provide the Bureau of Prisons with direct-hiring authority, which would allow individual facilities to hire the staff they need on their own timelines. This week, I was honored to accept the Legislative Appreciation Award from the Council of Prison Locals for my work on this issue and will continue to make sure the safety of correctional facility staff and inmates is a top priority.      Investing in Illinois Waterways I met with Illinois members of the Waterways Council to discuss the funding and maintenance of our system of inland waterways and ports. With millions of tons of cargo transported on the Mississippi River every year, this issue is one of my top priorities. As a member of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, I will continue to make sure Southern Illinois's waterways are taken care of.     Meeting with Southern Illinois Community Colleges Earlier in the week, I had the chance to meet with Interim President Dr. Kathleen Curphy and Don Patton with Shawnee Community College as well as several administrators and trustees from John A. Logan Community College to discuss access to grants, lowering costs of tuition, and bolstering job training for career and technical education (CTE) programs. As a member of the Congressional CTE Caucus, I will continue to support these critically important programs.   It was a productive week here in Washington, with a schedule jam-packed full of meeting with folks from across our district. I’m looking forward being back in Southern Illinois for our district work week.  I hope you enjoy Presidents' Day tomorrow and are able to relax and reflect on the blessings in your life. Enjoy your week!  -Mike                  Unsubscribe

As I said on the House floor, I am an equal to every one of my male colleagues in Congress until I walk out the door and down the steps of the Capitol. Then I am relegated to second-class status because women are not recognized in the Constitution as fully equal to men under the law. Thursday’s vote on H.J.Res.79, my resolution to facilitate ratification of the ERA, was a vote for equality, the American dream, and that more perfect union. I am proud of House Democrats, and five of our Republican colleagues, who joined me in championing the fight for women’s rights and greater equality. House Democrats also continued our work to protect our environment and natural spaces with a sweeping wilderness protection bill, and we voted to establish the first museum in the United States dedicated to the celebration and recognition of women’s history. We also turned the spotlight on threats to our nation with the Military Personnel Committee hearing that I chaired and that focused on the rise of white supremacy in our military, the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the malign actions of foreign adversaries including Russia and China, and my work to expose and eradicate the corrosive effects of sexual assault on our brave servicemembers – which threatens unit cohesion and military readiness. I was proud to introduce a resolution with Congressman Jim McGovern (D-MA) to establish an international anti-corruption court to address the impact that corruption has on human rights worldwide and the challenge of holding kleptocrats accountable for their crimes, and much more as you will read below. I am looking forward to being home in the 14th District this coming week. Then it’s back to Washington, DC the week of February 24th, and a return of Jackie’s DC Dashboard, so be sure to keep an eye out for the next update.                   As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.           Legislative Highlights Passed My Bill to Facilitate Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment  When Congress passed the ERA in 1972, it attached an arbitrary seven-year ratification deadline to the preamble which was later extended three more years. By 1982, 35 states out of the required 38 states voted to ratify the amendment. In the past three years, grassroots campaigns have successfully secured the final ratification votes in Nevada, Illinois, and most recently, Virginia. Unfortunately, the Department of Justice (DOJ) Office of Legal Counsel recently put out a legal opinion that the current ERA push is dead and that Congress lacks the authority to revive it. The Archivist, who is responsible for certifying amendments to the Constitution once ratified by three-fourths of the states, has decided to follow DOJ’s guidance even though Article V makes clear the Executive has no role in the Constitutional amendment process. Our vote to eliminate the arbitrary deadline brings us closer to placing this important guarantee of women’s equality in our founding document. It is now up to the Senate to follow suit and vote on companion legislation by Senators Murkowski and Cardin, and the Archivist to move forward with certifying the ERA.  Voted for Sweeping Wilderness Bill This week, the House took a major step toward protecting our public lands by voting to designate almost 1.4 million acres of land as wilderness and adding 1,000 river miles to the National Wild and Scenic River Systems. H.R. 2546, the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act, would preserve natural spaces in California, Colorado, and Washington for generations to come by protecting them from logging, mining, drilling, and new construction. It would also improve recreational access for underserved communities, safeguard ancestral homelands and tribal access, and boost local economies. Despite the bipartisan House vote, the Senate Majority Mitch McConnell is likely to relegate this critically-needed bill to his legislative graveyard. President Trump has also threatened to veto this legislation if it reaches his desk. But this fight is far from over. Our public lands are our most important natural heritage and an important tool in the fight against climate change. House Democrats will continue to push for wilderness and environmental protections as Americans across the continue to demand action this election year. Voted to Create a Smithsonian Women’s History Museum On Tuesday, House Democrats passed H.R. 1980, the Smithsonian Women’s History Museum Act. This bipartisan legislation would establish a Smithsonian museum dedicated to women’s history on the National Mall. Currently, we do not have a comprehensive museum in America documenting women’s history. Without it, women’s contributions to the nation are too often forgotten and could be lost as distant and forgotten memories. The stories of women in this country are too integral to our history to push aside. I was proud to vote for this historic legislation and urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly pass it so that we can get to work building this museum!    Where’s Jackie? Chaired MILPERS Hearing on White Supremacists in the Military  There are several warning signs that these efforts have found success. Recent high-profile examples include a Marine attending the 2017 Charlottesville rally, a Coast Guard officer arrested with a cache of weapons, and a West Point graduate espousing hate on social media. It seems that the military is not only not taking this threat seriously enough, it also lacks the tools it needs and has failed to dedicate sufficient resources to fighting this threat. At the hearing, we discussed necessary improvements to the accessions process, how we investigate and punish white supremacist activity in the forces, and how we report and track these individuals after they have been expelled from the military. I look forward to an update from military leadership soon on the progress that they will make in focusing on this issue with the seriousness and commitment that it demands. You can watch the hearing here.  House Armed Services Committee Hearing on Threats Posed by Russia and China This week, I attended the House Armed Services Committee hearing on the Defense Department’s role in our national efforts to address the threats and challenges posed by Russia and China—two formidable countries that do not share our values. The DoD is focused on ensuring that the United States is ready to compete with those countries militarily, but at the hearing we discussed the importance of addressing less traditional acts of aggression, such as propaganda operations, cyber-attacks, and predatory economic practices. Countering these threats will require a comprehensive strategy across our government, executed in partnership with our allies.  Spoke on a Panel about Military Sexual Assault  On Wednesday night, I attended Heroine, a one-woman show about a female soldier performed at the beautiful Kennedy Center. The play, which is based on a real story, describes a woman’s struggle with addiction, depression, and suicide after being raped by soldiers in her unit. I was deeply impressed by how the performance conveyed the horror of military sexual assault and lasting pains with which survivors must wrestle. After the play, I sat on a panel with military justice experts to discuss our ongoing efforts to address this issue. As the Chair of the Military Personnel Subcommittee, I have made eradicating military sexual violence a top priority because our military cannot succeed while battling this scourge within its ranks.     Meetings with Jackie Meeting with Local Veterans Affairs Department Union On Wednesday, I met with leaders of AFGE Local 2110, the union that represents workers at our local VA hospital and clinic. We discussed our ongoing efforts to improve VA locality pay to offset the high cost of living in our area and help the VA recruit and retain staff. The VA representatives also shared the way that the Trump Administration’s anti-union actions have constrained their ability to operate. I remain committed to helping AFGE as it fights for its members to receive a living wage and fair representation.  Met with Northern California Special Olympics Delegation  Met with the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District On Wednesday I met with representatives of the Golden Gate Bridge Highway and Transportation District (GGBHTD) to discuss opportunities for supporting San Francisco’s infrastructure needs. The District shared their plans for upcoming federal grant opportunities, and I look forward to lending my support to their work. We discussed the District’s concerns around the lack of federal funding to California for critical infrastructure needs, such as seismic retrofitting of the Golden Gate Bridge and expansion of the ferry boat system. I share many of their concerns, especially given President Trump’s vindictive attitude toward California.  The GGBHTD also provided updates on important projects and policies such as drone restrictions over the bridge, construction of the suicide net, and new safety measures for the bridge. The Golden Gate Bridge is an icon of the Bay Area as well as a vital piece of infrastructure for the region. I remain committed to supporting GGBHT and the needs of all Bay Area residents.    Voices of California’s 14th District  Here are some issues raised this week:   99 constituents expressed support for H.R. 230, the Ban Toxic Pesticides Act of 2019. I am a cosponsor of this crucial piece of legislation that would ban the use of the pesticide chlorpyrifos and prohibit any future registration of the pesticide. Please know that I will always fight to protect public health and safety, and ensure that our water, produce, and environment is safe from toxic chemicals. 87 constituents expressed concern with fracking.  Like you, I am deeply concerned about the effect of fracking on water sources. I take regulation of hydraulic fracturing seriously and will fight to protect the health and safety of all Americans. I am also deeply committed to supporting clean technology innovation, including solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, advanced biofuels, and other renewable energy sources 27 constituents expressed support for our public lands. Our landscapes and national parks are treasures that must be preserved for future generations. I am proud to have been named a "Friend of the National Parks," and I am committed to conserving our natural heritage. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                       Dear Lindsey,  This week, Senator Baldwin joined a group of 30 Senators, led by Senators Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH) and Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), in a letter to Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Andrew Wheeler requesting an updated timeline for when the EPA will implement commitments made in the agency’s plan to combat exposure to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). The EPA released its plan – the PFAS Action Plan – one year ago today and has yet to implement many of the commitments outlined in the strategy.    “As you are aware, communities across the country are struggling to respond to the widespread issue of PFAS contamination,” said Senator Baldwin and her colleagues. “ The human health risks from this class of chemicals, which include birth defects, various forms of cancer, and immune system dysfunction, are still being examined, and the uncertainty has caused great concern among our constituents.”   The lawmakers went on to underscore that the PFAS Action Plan alone is insufficient to address the full scope and urgency of the problems associated with PFAS exposure, which is why failure to take an initial step to implement this plan is particularly concerning. They also highlighted that the EPA committed to establishing federal drinking water standards last year for perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (PFOS), two of the most prevalent PFAS chemicals, but have also failed to follow through on that pledge. The Senators closed their letter with a request that the EPA provide an update on the status of every commitment made in the PFAS Action Plan, as well as an update on the timeline for executing the priorities included in the strategy. Senator Baldwin has long been leading efforts in the Senate to address water contamination from chemicals containing PFAS and ensure Wisconsinites have clean drinking water. Last summer, Senator Baldwin supported the bipartisan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2020 that includes a requirement that the military phase out the use of firefighting foam containing PFAS, prohibits the uncontrolled release of PFAS at military installations, and provides new tools for states to initiate environmental cleanup of PFAS at military facilities, including sites in Wisconsin like Truax Field.  Last fall, Senator Baldwin called on the Trump administration to respond more urgently to water contamination caused by PFAS in order to protect human health. In a letter to EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director Dr. Robert Redfield, Senator Baldwin demanded more EPA research to make PFAS testing more accessible and affordable and more research at CDC on how PFAS exposure harms human health, along with emphasizing the critical need for collaboration between the agencies to address this issue.  Senator Baldwin also helped introduce the bipartisan PFAS Accountability Act last year, which sets clear deadlines and reporting requirements for cleaning up PFAS contamination at federal facilities across the country, including active and decommissioned military bases, and mandates greater transparency.  It calls on federal facilities, including military and National Guard installations, to expedite cooperative agreements with states to address PFAS contamination. These agreements commit the federal government to take specific actions and enable states and local communities to be reimbursed for costs incurred to address PFAS contamination. In addition to helping introduce the bipartisan PFAS Accountability Act, Senator Baldwin has pressed the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Defense for answers after media reports that the agencies were trying to weaken PFAS groundwater cleanup guidelines. She also helped introduce the bipartisan PFAS Detection Act, which provides the U.S. Geological Survey with $45 million to develop new advanced technologies to detect PFAS and then to conduct nationwide sampling for PFAS in the environment. See a copy of the Senators’ letter to the EPA and read more about Senator Baldwin’s actions to establish enforceable drinking water standards and ensure Wisconsinites have clean drinking water here.                            Click to Unsubscribe

During the first half of February, I attended President Donald Trump's inspiring State of the Union address, traveled with President Trump for the Opportunity Now Summit, and met with school leaders on education issues. I also had the opportunity to personally award the winner of the Congressional App Challenge. Below you can also find information on this year's Congressional Art Competition.  State of the Union Address In President Donald Trump's State of the Union address, he reaffirmed his commitment to keeping his promises.  South Carolina has seen his kept promises first-hand. At 2.3 percent, South Carolina’s unemployment rate is at a record low. Since President Trump’s election, 122,000 jobs have been created in South Carolina—including 19,000 manufacturing jobs, wages increased 4 percent by an average of $5,000 for families in South Carolina. Read my full statement on the President's State of the Union address here.   Opportunity NOW Summit  I was grateful to travel with President Trump for the launch of Opportunity NOW, a new nationwide campaign to revitalize under-served cities and towns across America.    Opportunity NOW Summit   Meetings with Midlands Technical College and Magnet Schools of America This week I met with the Midlands Technical College Board of Trustees to talk about the importance of technical colleges which teach the skills necessary to succeed in our dynamic workforce.   Meeting with Midlands Technical College  Last week, I was recognized by the Magnet Schools of America (MSA) as a Champion of Magnet School Excellence and to be a steadfast supporter of magnet schools, in South Carolina and nationally.    Meeting with the Magnet Schools of America     Congressional App Challenge Winner Congratulations to Milan Dutta of Lexington for winning the Congressional App Challenge for South Carolina’s Second District with his app, “BioHelper.” The Congressional App Challenge is open to all middle and high school students in South Carolina’s Second District. Every year, the winner from the Second District is featured online and the winning app will be eligible to be displayed in the United States Capitol. Details on the 2020 competition will be announced in October.    Awarding the Congressional App Challenge Winner, Milan Dutta of Lexington    Congressional Art Competition Each year, my colleagues and I in the House of Representatives participate in a nationwide high school arts competition sponsored by the Congressional Institute. The Congressional Art Competition is a way to recognize the talent of young artists here in the Second Congressional District of South Carolina and across the nation. This competition is open to all high school students, and one winner is selected to represent the Second District. The winning artwork will be displayed for one year in the U.S. Capitol along with art from all participating districts around the country. This is truly a spectacular exhibit - one that I encourage all to come and see if you are ever in Washington.     More information on how to enter and competition guidelines can be found here.   Sincerely, Member Of Congress                     Washington, DC Office1436 Longworth House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515phone: (202) 225-2452fax: (202) 225-2455   The Midlands Office1700 Sunset Blvd (US 378), Suite 1West Columbia, SC 29169phone: (803) 939-0041fax: (803) 939-0078   Aiken/Barnwell Office1930 University Parkway, Suite 1600Aiken, SC 29801phone: (803) 642-6416fax: (803) 642-6418                     Unsubscribe | Privacy   Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email

Date:     Thursday 20 February 2020  Time:    4:00 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.  Place:   Hammer Theatre at San Jose State University  101 Paseo de San Antonio (between 2nd and 3rd Streets), San Jose  The Town Hall Meeting is open to constituents of the 18th and 19th Congressional Districts on a first-come, first-served basis, and space is limited. Please RSVP in advance. Doors will open at 3:30 p.m., and if anyone requires special accommodations, please call Rep. Eshoo's Palo Alto office at 650-323-2984.  Highlights of What I Did in Congress This Week  Hearing on Women’s Access to Reproductive Health Care   As Chairwoman of the Health Subcommittee, I held the first legislative hearing in 20 years to protect women’s reproductive health and considered the Women’s Health Protection Act. This bill ensures that every American woman has equal access to comprehensive reproductive health care no matter where they live. Since 2011, states have passed more than 450 medically unnecessary restrictions on reproductive care. Today, 90 percent of counties in our country are without a single abortion provider, and six states have only one clinic. The Women’s Health Protection Act creates a safeguard against bans and medically unnecessary restrictions. The bill also protects women’s freedom to make decisions about their own reproductive health care. You can watch video of my opening statement HERE.  Voted YES on the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act  I voted for the Protecting America’s Wilderness Act, a package of six bills that protect public lands and waters in California, Colorado, and Washington. The bill designates approximately 1.3 million acres of wilderness, the strongest level of protection for federal land, and incorporates more than 1,000 river miles into the National Wild and Scenic River Systems (NWSRS). The legislation includes four key initiatives centered on protection for California landscapes and increased access to the outdoors:  The Northwest California Wilderness, Recreation, and Working Forests Act   The Central Coast Heritage Act   The San Gabriel Mountains Foothills and Rivers Protection Act   The Rim of the Valley Corridor Preservation Act  The legislation boosts recreation opportunities in California and preserves hundreds of thousands of acres of California wilderness, among other conservation initiatives to protect forests, habitats, and wild and scenic rivers. You can read detailed descriptions of the legislation here.  Voted YES to Remove the Deadline for the Ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment   The Equal Rights Amendment (ERA) simply states:  “Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or any State on account of sex.”  The ERA would finally affirm women’s equality in our Constitution and strictly prohibit sex discrimination. The amendment passed the House and Senate with bipartisan support in 1971 and 1972, but it included a clause requiring ratification by 1979, which was later extended before it expired in 1982. At the time of expiration, 35 of the 38 required state legislatures had voted to ratify the ERA. Nevada ratified the ERA in 2017, Illinois in 2018 and, in January 2020, Virginia became the 38th state to ratify it. I voted to pass a resolution to remove the arbitrary 1982 deadline and take a critical step toward ensuring the ERA officially becomes the 28th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Onward!  Legislation Anna Introduced and Cosponsored this Week  America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act  Our national parks and wildernesses are American treasures. Sadly, the Trump Administration continues their campaign to auction off these treasures to oil and gas corporations. The America’s Red Rock Wilderness Act will protect more than 8 million acres of Utah, including the Great Basin, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Moab-La Sal Canyons, Henry Mountains, Glen Canyon, San Juan-Anasazi, Canyonlands Basin, San Rafael Swell, Book Cliffs, and Uinta Basin. By designating these areas as wildernesses, wildlife will be protected, ancestral lands preserved, and access protected for future generations of hikers and environmental enthusiasts.  Housing Is Infrastructure Act  Rising housing costs continue to force more and more middle- and working-class residents to leave our region in search of affordable housing. This is unacceptable and threatens the composition and identity of our local communities. To address the affordable housing crisis, I cosponsored the Housing is Infrastructure Act which provides $100 billion for effective but underfunded federal programs to increase the supply of affordable housing.  Letters Anna Wrote this Week  Letter to FCC Chairman Ajit Pai Demanding Action on Russian Propaganda  This week I wrote my seventh letter to Federal Communications (FCC) Chairman Ajit Pai, urging him to investigate Russian state-sponsored media outlets broadcasting propaganda in the U.S. The U.S. Intelligence Community has concluded that Russian state-sponsored media meddled in our national elections when they pushed anti-U.S. messaging over American broadcast airwaves, and Russian state-sponsored media continues to air on American stations. The FCC is required to identify foreign propaganda on American airwaves, but under Chairman Pai’s leadership, the Commission has failed to enforce its own rules. The FCC’s continued inaction is a stunning abdication of its responsibility to protect Americans from malicious interference in our elections from a foreign adversary. As voters decide who we will elect to lead our country, it’s critical that we are not influenced by foreign propaganda. You can read my letter here.   Weekly Highlights  Lyme Champion Award    It was a wonderful honor to receive the Lyme Champion Award from the Center for Lyme Action for my work to advance research and awareness for Lyme Disease. Through my legislation the Department of Health and Human Services has convened a working group of experts to review existing research and identify gaps in our understanding of tick-borne diseases. This has culminated in a report with recommendations for the federal government to address vector borne disease. Lyme disease is a debilitating condition and it’s one of the fastest growing infectious diseases in the United States with over 300,000 new cases diagnosed every year. Thank you to Center For Lyme Action co-founder Bonnie Crater of Portola Valley and all the Center’s advocates for your efforts to combat this terrible disease and for the generous award.  In the Words of My Constituents  Every week hundreds of my constituents call and write to me to express their concerns, share their passions, and ask questions regarding legislation and policies. Over 10,067 constituents have already contacted me in 2020. I actually read every communication and every constituent receives a personal response to their specific questions and comments from me. This week, 1,353 constituents contacted our office about issues including:   181 constituents wrote to me in opposition of fracking   61 constituents wrote to me in support of eliminating the time limit on the ERA ratification   50 constituents wrote to me in support of the Banning Toxic Pesticides Act  Anna's Recommended Reading and Watching   I frequently read articles or see videos that I think my constituents would benefit from.   Washington Post Opinion (2/13/2020) – “Health-care workers are the front-line warriors against coronavirus. We must protect them.”  Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy Director Michael Osterholm and Documentarian Mark Olshaker make the strong case to prioritize health-care workers and first responders when it comes to the distribution of protective health equipment. To minimize the threat of coronavirus, we must ensure our health providers are healthy enough to perform their duties. Friendly Reminder  U.S. Census Job Openings  The U.S. Census Bureau needs to hire more workers in the Bay Area for the 2020 Census. They have temporary supervisory, outreach, and recruiting positions available, the pay is competitive, and the work is critical to obtaining an accurate count for next year’s census. You can find more information on available positions here.  Sincerely,   Anna G. Unlike a Congressional budget, the President's budget lays out the Administration’s priories for the upcoming year with recommended spending levels. I visited the White House on Tuesday and met with the acting director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Russ Vought. We discussed many of the President’s funding priorities and how they could strengthen Eastern and Southeastern Ohio. The budget includes funding for rural broadband expansion, opioid treatment, the border wall, and the Appalachian Regional Commission. The President has made it clear with this budget proposal that he is continuing to prioritize rural America.  Now having the Administration’s input, it is up to Congress to pass a budget that actually becomes law. This is the second year in a row that House Democrats have no intentions of releasing a budget. In order to address our deficit and out-of-control government spending, I’m hopeful they’ll decide to show some fiscal responsibility by - at a very minimum - passing a budget.     Ohio Fraternal Order of Police Visit   This week I met with representatives from the Ohio Fraternal Order of Police, the “protector of the protectors.” I gladly thanked them for all they do for the men and women in blue, and we discussed legislation to promote safety and fairness for law enforcement and the communities they serve. I’ll always stand with our police and other first responders.     Problem Solvers Caucus  Based on the overwhelmingly negative coverage from the mainstream media, one could easily conclude that Congress doesn’t work together on anything. But I can tell you - that is simply not true. I’m a member of a bipartisan group of 48 Republicans and Democrats called the Problem Solvers Caucus. We meet regularly and work hard to reach across the aisle to find real solutions to problems facing America - issues like upgrading our infrastructure, expanding broadband access to rural America, and making prescription drugs more affordable, just to name a few. Just last week, the House approved “Problem Solvers” legislation, that I cosponsored, to strengthen the U.S. Postal Service by eliminating outdated rules that currently make it financially difficult for the USPS to fulfill its mission effectively. This week, I joined my Problem Solvers Caucus colleagues at a press conference to talk about what we have accomplished and what our caucus is looking to work on moving forward. This bipartisan group agrees that we were sent to Congress to govern, and to work TOGETHER to serve the American people.     Union Local High School Visit   One of my most favorite parts of serving you in Congress is being able to talk with young people - the next generation of America’s leaders - and listening to what they’re most concerned about and interested in. I had a great conversation with students from Union Local in Belmont County earlier this week that touched on a range of issues, including the opioid epidemic, rural broadband, and even the Congressional baseball game for charity, which I play in every year. It was a great discussion and I’m glad they stopped by.    Thank you again for subscribing to my weekly District Download. It is important to remember that Congress holds the power of the purse. The President's budget is merely a reflection of his priorities and a suggestion to the House and Senate. His proposal demonstrates his commitment to decreasing our national debt and balancing our federal budget, and we can use his proposal to guide our discussions in Congress. I am proud to serve on the powerful Appropriations Committee, which sets the funding levels for discretionary spending, and we have a lot of work to do. We have already started hosting Appropriations Subcommittee hearings to discuss funding for different departments and offices of the federal government. One place where I believe the President's budget proposal fell short was at Hanford. Since I came to Congress, every Administration has proposed cuts to the Hanford cleanup, and I have worked across the aisle to restore funding. Federal dollars are critical to ensuring the men and women of the Hanford workforce are able to safely and efficiently clean up the millions of gallons of nuclear waste at the Hanford Site, keep our groundwater and the Columbia River safe from contamination, and fulfill the federal government's promise to the Tri-Cities community.     The Columbian: "In Our View: Nuclear waste requires innovative solutions"  President Trump's proposal also did not include funding for the licensing of Yucca Mountain, which is a change from his previous position. It is the law of the land: Yucca Mountain is the nation's sole permanent repository for nuclear waste. With 56 gallons of nuclear waste at the Hanford Site alone, no district in the United States is more dependent on Yucca Mountain than Washington's 4th. I have met personally with the President to urge him to reconsider his change in position.  As we continue through the Appropriations process, I will work to represent Central Washington's priorities and ensure the federal government fulfills its moral and legal obligation to clean up the Hanford Site.   Healthy Forests Prevent Wildfires   In Central Washington, we understand how important active land management is for wildfire prevention. I am proud to support commonsense land management practices and policies that both protect our national forests and communities from wildfires but also protect the environment. My friend, Rep. Westerman, recently introduced the Trillion Trees Act that would plant 1 trillion trees by 2050 and incentivize the use of wood products as carbon sequestration devices. This week, I visited with U.S. Forest Service Chief Vicki Christiansen and attended a Summit on Active Forest Management and Wildfire Suppression, hosted by the Western Caucus, to discuss Rep. Westerman's proposal and several ways we can promote healthy forests and sustain our public lands. Native Communities Have Had Enough   Patricia Whitefoot has been an incredible advocate for Native women and a critical ally for me as we work in Congress to address the crisis of missing and murdered indigenous women. She joined me in the nation's Capitol to discuss our legislative efforts like Savanna's Act that - for too long - have been stalled in the Judiciary Committee. I have met with tribal leaders across the Pacific Northwest to hear how this crisis is affecting our communities. One thing is clear: Native communities have had enough. We cannot continue to drag our feet while the loved ones of these women wait for answers.  Calling All High School Artists: Congressional Art Competition   The 2020 Central Washington Congressional Art Competition is now OPEN! This competition is an opportunity for students in Central Washington to tell a story and express themselves through art. Year after year, I am impressed by the talent and creativity of these young people. I look forward to seeing the new submissions!  The Art Competition is open to all high school students in Washington's 4th Congressional District. The winner's artwork will hang in the U.S. Capitol for one year, and the winning artist will receive two plane tickets to Washington D.C. Find more details, rules, and regulations on my website.   To stay current on the work I am doing around the District and in Washington D.C., I encourage you to follow me  on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and to read updates on my website.  It is an honor and a privilege to represent you in Congress. Twelve years ago, five students lost their lives at a mass shooting at Northern Illinois University. Two years ago, 14 students and 3 staff members were killed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida. One year ago, five people lost their lives and many more were injured when a gunman entered an Aurora, Illinois warehouse. Enough is enough. At last year’s vigil in Aurora, I vowed to take legislative action to combat this epidemic of gun violence. But in states like Illinois, these efforts are often undermined by traffickers coming from Indiana and other states with looser laws. In Chicago, 60% of the guns recovered from crime scenes are trafficked in from out of state. Earlier this week, to stem this onslaught, I introduced the Gun Trafficker Detection Act with Rep.Ted Deutch (FL-22) and Robin Kelly (IL-02).  The bill would create a federal requirement that gun owners must report their gun if lost or stolen within 48 hours. This helps law enforcement identify and prosecute traffickers, who often claim their gun was lost or stolen when it turns up at a crime scene across state lines. The bill also makes traffickers liable for any damage done by their guns and makes repeat violators ineligible to buy firearms for five years. Yesterday, I spoke on the floor in favor of my bill.    To watch my floor speech, click the image above or click here.   The people of Illinois have been loud and clear: We want to keep our friends and family safe from the scourge of gun violence. The Gun Trafficker Detection Act will help law enforcement address the spread of guns from states with lax gun laws.  I promise to never stop fighting for gun violence prevention measures that make our communities and schools safer. As your Representative, I work for you and want to hear your priorities and concerns. To keep up with the work I’m doing in Congress, follow my social media or subscribe to my newsletter. name: Congresswoman Elise Stefanik
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                    February 14, 2020               Home About Me Contact Media Center Services                     Passing Bill Increasing the Number of Agricultural Specialists for U.S. Customs and Border Protection  This week, I voted in favor of the Protecting America’s Food and Agriculture Act, legislation I proudly cosponsored. This bill authorizes U.S. Customs and Border Protection to add 240 new U.S. Customs and Border Protection Agriculture Specialists, 20 agriculture canine teams, and additional support staff in the Office of Field Operations each fiscal year. This is expected to continue until the number of specialists sustains the requirements put forward by the Agriculture Resource Allocation Model. It is in the best interest of our national security to ensure that our food supply is sufficiently protected from any outside interference. In my many visits to our Northern Border, I have witnessed firsthand the need for more staffers who are specifically trained in this area. I proudly voted in favor of this legislation to provide adequate resources and staffing at our borders and protect our country’s food and agriculture interests. Read more here,   Urging FDA Action on Dairy Labeling Rules  This week, I sent a letter to the new Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Commissioner Steven Hahn, urging him to take action to enforce the FDA standards of identity that are already in place for dairy products. The FDA has formal rules surrounding the definition of labeling genuine dairy products and alternatives that they have chosen not to enforce for several years. I am also cosponsor of the Dairy PRIDE Act, a House bill that would amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to prohibit the sale of any food that uses the market name of a dairy product but does not come from an animal, and does not contain milk as a primary ingredient. This letter to the FDA is the next step in urging them to act on dairy labeling issues. For far too long, the FDA has failed to combat the misuse of dairy terms on non-dairy products. Not only does this cause confusion among consumers, but it also puts our North Country dairy farmers at a disadvantage in the grocery store. Real dairy products come from real cows, and they should be the only products labeled as “milk”. I will continue to be an outspoken advocate and urge FDA to enforce existing law. Read more here.   Dropping the Puck in Glens Falls to Stick It to Cancer and Helping Kids Learn to Skate   This past weekend, I had the pleasure of attending the community "Try Hockey for Free" event in Glens Falls, where I helped introduce many young constituents to the sport of hockey. This great event was hosted by the New York Rangers hockey team.  I also had the opportunity to participate in the puck drop at the Adirondack Thunder game. NY-21 is hockey country, and it is amazing to see our youth carry on the tradition!  Meeting with Constituents and Groups Important to the North Country    I met with the Agriculture Retailers Association to discuss their priorities, including agriculture labor reform, infrastructure, rural broadband, and the importance of training the next generation of our workforce.    It was great to meet with constituents and representatives from the Center for Lyme Action to discuss the important work they are doing. In Congress, I work diligently to promote prevention and treatment for Lyme disease. I am a cosponsor of the TICK Act, legislation to establish an office of oversight and coordination for tick-borne diseases. I will continue to support increased funding for research into this disease that affects many of my constituents and many people throughout the country.   I also met with General Joseph M. Martin, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army. We discussed many issues facing Fort Drum, including improvements to childcare facilities and childcare facility worker hiring standards. I look forward to prioritizing the Army's requests for the upcoming National Defense Authorization Act. I am proud to be the number one advocate for Fort Drum in Congress. Cosponsoring the Forest Recovery Act  This week, I cosponsored the bipartisan Forest Recovery Act, legislation that will support timber farmers who have been affected by catastrophic loss events. The bill will help forest landowners recover from natural disasters by eliminating the basis limitation rule and allowing them to deduct up to the fair market value of their devastated trees. This levels the playing field for timber farmers who have been impacted by events like extreme weather and forest fires. Farmers across many sectors continue to be impacted by extreme weather events, and not all of them are protected by crop insurance. This bipartisan bill will help timber producers continue their business, which will have a positive impact on many of our North Country communities who include timber production as part of their economic base. Read more here.  Cosponsoring Bill to Ensure All Active Duty Overseas Military Ballots Are Counted  I also became a cosponsor of the Counting All Military Votes Act, legislation to make Express Mail Labels available to deployed active duty military serving on our embassies, consulates, and/or in diplomatic posts. This will ensure each of their absentee votes will be successfully delivered on time by Express Mail in order to be counted. As the Representative of the 10th Mountain Division, the most deployed unit in the U.S. Army, our district understands that their participation in the electoral process is critical. Our brave men and women serving in active duty overseas assignments deserve a say in our government and elected leaders. Each of their votes must be counted, and this legislation ensures expedited mailing for their absentee ballots. We are forever indebted to those who sacrifice daily while fighting for our freedom and I’m honored to advocate for our great servicemembers in Congress. Read more here.  Announcing Housing Development Funding for Glens Falls and Watertown  I was thrilled to announce United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) funding for Glens Falls and Watertown. The Community Planning and Development Program Formula Allocations provide grants to states and local units of government to develop viable urban communities by providing decent housing and a suitable living environment, and by expanding economic opportunities, specifically for low- and moderate-income communities.  Glens Falls will receive $490,696 in funding and the City of Watertown will receive $920,779 in Community Development Block (CDBG) Grants, which will be used to support housing initiatives in both towns. Affordable housing is a prominent issue in many areas in my district, and initiatives like this help communities to provide more affordable and suitable opportunities. I will continue to advocate for programs that enable our local communities to support those in need of assistance. Read more here.   Writing an Op-Ed Commemorating the 40th Anniversary of the Miracle on Ice   This week, I wrote an op-ed commemorating the 40th anniversary of the iconic Miracle on Ice and celebrating the North Country’s rich Olympic history. The op-ed was published in The Sun this week. Read it here.  As always, thank you for subscribing to my weekly updates!    Sincerely,    Elise StefanikMember of Congress             Social Media Corner:       ___________________  Featured Read:   Times Union: State, federal lawmakers clash over access to DMV records      U.S. Rep. Elise Stefanik, R-Schuylerville, a staunch opponent of the Green Light Law, criticized Democrats for "absolutely [leaving] out federal agencies" as they decided to bar immigration officials from accessing DMV databases. Stefanik, whose district abuts the Canadian border, argued that federal officials must access DMV records to check license plates and stop possible criminals from crossing international lines – though she did not draw a connection explicitly between a lack of access to DMV databases and applications for travel perks.  "New York state should repeal the Green Light Law," Stefanik, who is an enrollee in the Global Entry program, said in an interview Monday afternoon. "They should stop prioritizing illegal immigrants over law-abiding citizens."                   _______________  Constituent Services  Please contact my Glens Falls office at (518) 743-0964 if you would like help with:   Federal agencies. Glens Falls Office  5 Warren Street, Suite 4  Glens Falls, NY 12801  _________________  Weekly Legislative Recap  Below find a list of legislation that the House of Representatives voted on this week. It was a very eventful week and I'm excited to tell you about what we accomplished. Here are some highlights:   I was the Grand Marshall for the Ninth Annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade I toured the Indian River Lagoon to see living shorelines and learn more about preserving our environment I attended the signing of the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act by President Trump at the White House I spoke on the House floor in recognition of Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune and her contributions to our community and country  CELEBRATING OUR RACING HISTORY: This weekend I had the honor of serving as the Grand Marshall of this year’s Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade! Since the 1920s, Daytona Beach has been the home of NASCAR, with drivers setting records racing down our beach to the famous North Turn and A1A. This race is an important part of our community’s history and it’s always one of my favorite events every year!    Serving as Grand Marshall at the 9th annual Historic North Turn Legends Beach Parade  CONSERVING OUR SHORELINE: Our beautiful and natural shorelines can co-exist with development when done correctly. Living shorelines and mangroves are important for our communities because they are the best natural barriers against storm surges. Estuaries and mangroves are also important to commercial fisherman. Around 80 percent of them rely on estuaries and mangroves for spawning. I enjoyed touring our local living shorelines to learn more about how conservancies bring free market, volunteering and community based solutions to our community. It's important we maintain our living shorelines to help keep Florida resilient.     Views of our Indian River Lagoon living shoreline  SUPPORTING OUR VETERANS: This week, I went to the White House to see President Trump sign another bill supporting our veterans into law — and this time, it was a bill I co-sponsored! The Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act supports our veterans, helping them find opportunities for jobs in STEM fields when they return to civilian life. I was glad to work on this bill with two fellow Florida congressmen, Senator Marco Rubio and Congressman Neal Dunn, and I was proud to be there as the President signed it into law!    President Trump signing the Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act into law RECOGNIZING SERVANT LEADERSHIP: I can't think of anyone better to highlight great servant leadership in our community and our country this Black History Month than our district's very own Dr. Mary McLeod Bethune. Bethune founded and was President of the all African-American girls school in Daytona Beach, which later became Bethune–Cookman University. Bethune selflessly dedicated herself to fighting for the equality and civil rights of all Americans through education and because of her, Florida and America are a better place.  Click below to watch me honor Dr. Bethune on the House floor:    Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service.  In Service,    Michael Waltz                Washington, DC 216 Cannon House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2706 Deland Office 120 South Florida Ave.Suite 324Deland, FL 32720Phone: (386) 279-0707 Palm Coast Office 31 Lupi CourtSuite 130Palm Coast, FL 32137Phone: (386)-302-0442 Port Orange Office Port Orange City Hall1000 City Center Circle2nd FloorPort Orange, FL 32129Phone: (386) 238-9711          Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version

The Senator also joined his colleagues in Utah's Congressional delegation in commemorating Utah's role in the women's suffrage movement and met with several groups of Utahns visiting Washington.           150 years ago today, Seraph Young became the first woman to vote in Utah. It would be another 50 years until the 19th Amendment extended voting rights to women throughout the country. Utah women led the way. Senator Romney joined his Utah delegation colleagues Senator Lee and Congressmen Bishop, Stewart, Curtis, and McAdams to honor Utah's role in the women's suffrage movement. You can watch their tribute below:   Senator Romney spoke on the Senate floor to commemorate the leading role of Utahns in the fight for women’s suffrage. After he concluded his remarks, the Senate unanimously passed the resolution he introduced with Senator Lee recognizing Utah’s leading role in the suffrage movement and celebrating the sesquicentennial of the first votes by women under an equal suffrage law on February 14, 1870.   As the fourth most visited national park in the country, Zion is a pillar of the local tourism economy, helping support jobs and generate revenue. Senator Romney led the Utah delegation in sending a letter to Interior Secretary Bernhardt opposing a reservation system which the National Park Service has proposed for Zion National Park that would restrict visitor access and have negative impacts on the local economy.   Full story by Kathy Stephenson here.   This week, Senator Romney opened a new office in St. George to better serve residents of Southern Utah, reaffirming his commitment to ensuring Utahns continue to receive the assistance they need on issues related to Social Security, Medicare, veterans' benefits, and other federal matters. Office information, as well as information on how to schedule an appointment, can be found on our website.   Senator Romney met with Navajo Nation President Jonathan Nez to update him on the status of the Navajo Utah Water Rights Settlement Act, legislation he introduced with Arizona Senators McSally and Sinema. This week, its companion House legislation, led by Congressmen Bishop and Curtis, advanced out of the House Natural Resources Committee. The Senator applauded the committee's advancement of the legislation and urged for its immediate consideration in the Senate, saying: "There is no reason to wait any longer to resolve this longstanding issue."     January's vaping rules fall short of protecting our nation's youth and the public health. Senator Romney led a group of colleagues in sending a letter to the director of the Center for Tobacco Products expressing their concerns and requesting answers about devices, flavor requirements, and the Premarket Tobacco Product Applications process as the FDA implements the guidance saying: "Despite mounting evidence that flavors are a key driver of youth [e-cigarette] use, the January Guidance has glaring policy gaps that keep kids addicted to flavored products." The letter can be found here.   At a time when Libya's civil war poses a threat to U.S. interests, clarifying the U.S.-Libya strategy, including defining who our friends are, will help protect our regional interests. During a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing examining the Administration's Libya strategy, Senator Romney urged the Administration to unequivocally communicate its posture toward Libya on the global stage.     Senator Romney met with several groups of Utahns this week, including:   Representatives from the Utah Medical Association.   Representatives from Southern Utah University.   Davis County Commissioner Bob Stevenson.   Olha, a Ukranian student living in Utah through the State Department's Future Leaders Exchange program.   Warren, a Utah student who was awarded the Center for Native American Youth Champion for Change.                                                                  Unsubscribe

Select "Always display images" or  Click here to open in browser.                       Equal Rights for Women!             A Milestone for Equality This week, the House took action to move our nation closer to our founding ideal that all are created equal by passing H.J. Res 79. This resolution would remove the arbitrary deadline for the ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment.  One hundred years after women won the right to vote, it is a shameful reality that the Equal Rights Amendment still has not been enshrined in the Constitution.  As a result, millions of American women still face inequality under the law and injustice in their careers and lives, including a devastating wage gap, pregnancy discrimination and sexual harassment in the workplace. Currently, without the ERA, the Constitution does not guarantee equality between men and women.         By passing this resolution, the House is paving the way to enshrining Equal Rights Amendment in the Constitution, which will achieve justice for women and progress for families by increasing paychecks so moms can pay for their family's needs such as rent, groceries, childcare and health care.  The Equal Rights Amendment will strengthen America, unleashing the full power of women in our economy and upholding the value of equality in our democracy.  Because when Women succeed, America succeeds!       Congresswoman Pelosi joins House Democrats for a press conference ahead of the vote to remove the ratification deadline for the Equal Rights Amendment.      An Insult to Americans President Trump’s latest budget continues his relentless attacks on the health and economic security of hard-working Americans.  It is a complete reversal of the promises he made in the campaign and a contradiction of the statements he made at the State of the Union. The President has broken his promises to seniors and families by slashing half a trillion dollars from Medicare, taking $900 billion from the lifeline of Medicaid, and cutting Social Security Disability Insurance. Two-thirds of long-term care is payed for by Medicaid.  It is a middle class benefit.  These cuts endanger the health of seniors in long-term care needs for them and their families.  They also hurt rural hospitals, people seeking opioid addiction treatment, veterans and their families.  At the same time, the President is in court fighting to overturn the Affordable Care Act which has the pre-existing condition benefit and is important to families. Our federal budget should be a statement of our national values.  Once again, the President is showing just how little he values the good health, financial security and well-being of hard-working American families.  The President's budget is anti-growth, does not create good-paying jobs and increases the national debt.        Protecting Americans This week, with the strong War Powers Resolution to limit the President’s military action in Iran, the Senate joined the House to honor the first responsibility we have as Members of Congress: to keep the American people safe.  The President’s reckless decision to engage in hostilities against Iran without consulting Congress continues to endanger our servicemembers, diplomats and others.  Yet, for weeks now, the Administration has kept the Congress and American people in the dark about its actions and lack of strategy, including the resulting threats to our troops.  More than 100 American servicemembers have been diagnosed with Traumatic Brain Injury from Iran’s retaliatory strike. The House has maintained a drumbeat of action to limit the President’s dangerous military action and to save American lives by passing our War Powers Resolution, in addition to legislation to repeal the 2002 Iraq Authorization for Use of Military Force and legislation to prohibit funding for military action against Iran not authorized by Congress.  Now, we will prepare to take up Senator Kaine’s War Powers Resolution in the coming weeks. The President needs to listen to the will of Congress and the American people and work with Congress on a de-escalatory strategy that will protect American lives and interests.  America and the world cannot afford war.               A constituent contacted my office recently because his wife and child’s immigrant visas were affected by the Presidential Proclamation 9645. The office followed up with the US Embassy to provide more information regarding the situation of the constituent and his family.  As a result, the constituent and his family were recommended for a visa wavier and their applications were recently approved. Caseworkers in my San Francisco office work to address any problems or concerns you may have with a federal government agency. To submit a Casework Authorization Form, please visit my website.       Please feel free to forward this information to your family and friends. To learn more about these efforts, express your views, or sign up for email updates, please visit my website.          best regards,           This mailing was prepared, published and mailed at taxpayer expense Unsubscribe                WASHINGTON, DC 1236 Longworth HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4965 DISTRICT OFFICE 90 7th Street, Suite 2-800San Francisco, CA 94103Phone: (415) 556-4862                      /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }   p { margin-bottom:1em; }

Now that this sham impeachment is finally behind us, I’m hopeful Democrats will finally move on and return to legislating. On Monday, I joined Maria Bartiromo on Fox Business Network to discuss the need for Congress to get back to work for the American people.   Click  or on the image above to watch   Great News for Gilmer County Last spring, I wrote a letter to U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue in support of the Elijay Telephone Company’s application requesting grant funds to provide fiber broadband service to several unserved areas in Gilmer County. I’m proud to share with you that USDA recently granted our request, awarding Elijay Telephone Company with a $4.4 million grant to deploy high-speed broadband infrastructure throughout Gilmer County. This strong investment will support the construction of 90 miles of fiber-optic infrastructure in a service area that includes 2,159 households and 22 poultry farms. Throughout my time in Congress, I’ve worked not only to expand Georgians’ access to rural broadband, but to provide Georgians with more choices when it comes to service providers. Small internet service providers – like Ellijay Telephone Company – can help make that happen, which is why this grant funding falls right in line with the mission voiced by the Trump Administration to better connect rural America.   Protecting the Lives of the Unborn This week, House Democrats brought H.J. Res. 79 – legislation that would remove the already expired deadline to ratify the so-called “Equal Rights Amendment” – to the House floor. Contrary to Democrats’ claims, H. J. Res. 79 isn’t about protecting women – it’s about eliminating any law regulating abortion. If Democrats got their way and this bill was signed into law, the unlimited right to take an unborn child’s life would forever be enshrined in the Constitution.  I believe we, as a society, share a universal duty to protect the most defenseless humans among us — those living in the womb. One person’s reproductive right cannot outweigh another person’s right to live. For my family, protecting life is deeply personal. Click here or on the image below to hear our story.   To watch my remarks on the House floor, click here or on the image above   Standing Up for Religious Liberty As a pastor and a chaplain in the U.S. Air Force Reserve, I understand that the First Amendment guards the personal exercise of faith, and I firmly believe we cannot grow weary in fighting to protect Americans’ religious liberty. As Our Lady of Guadalupe School v. Morrissey-Berru heads to the Supreme Court, I led my colleagues in signing an amicus brief in support of Our Lady of Guadalupe School’s religious liberty. The teaching of religious principles and customs is at the very core of faith for many, if not most, religions. Yet in the opinion under review, the court barely addressed the importance of this aspect of religion. To read more about this case and our efforts to protect religious liberty, click here.   This week, I joined Laura Ingraham on Fox News to discuss the Democrats’ latest attack on President Trump. Click here or on the image above to watch.   Modernizing our Criminal Justice System Under current prison regulations, inmates who use the email system at Bureau of Prison facilities must consent to government review of their attorney-client communications, the contents of which can be accessed by prosecutors. However, other forms of communication, including telephone calls, currently receive protections under attorney-client privilege. This week, the House Judiciary Committee passed my bill, the Effective Assistance of Counsel in the Digital Era Act, to modernize our criminal justice system by extending attorney-client privilege to electronic communications, allowing incarcerated individuals to communicate with their attorneys efficiently and privately. Attorney-client privilege is a pivotal part of our legal system because it helps ensure fairness to all individuals, and I’m glad to have partnered with my colleagues to introduce this bill.   It’s always a good day when Northeast Georgians visit my D.C. office, especially Sheriff Stacy Nicholson of Gilmer County. As the son of a Georgia State Trooper, I have seen firsthand the sacrifices our officers make to keep us safe. Today and every day, I’m thankful for our law enforcement officers’ dedication and commitment to service.   Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in the Ninth District. To stay up to date on what’s happening each week, follow me on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.  Please don’t hesitate to contact my office if we can ever be of service.
