body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }            News From Congressman Ben Cline                    Sixth District Perspectives with Congressman Ben Cline  With impeachment behind us in the House, my colleagues and I were able to get back to work for the American people this week. Not only did the President sign USMCA into law, but the House also voted to save lives with the renewal of the classification of fentanyl as a Schedule I narcotic. I was also proud to introduce a new piece of legislation that, once passed, will ensure employees of the U.S. Marshals Service are eligible for parity of danger pay while serving in certain regions abroad. Further, I was pleased to honor Botetourt County on the House Floor as they are set to celebrate their 250th anniversary. It was a productive week in Washington, but I am pleased to be spending the weekend back in the Sixth District with those I represent.   Danger Pay for U.S. Marshals:   The U.S. Marshals Service often works alongside their DEA and FBI counterparts on dangerous missions abroad. From working to combat transnational criminal organizations to interrupting human trafficking rings, the brave men and women of the U.S. Marshals Service put their lives on the line to ensure the safety and security of American citizens. Yet under the current statute, Marshals do not qualify for danger pay in certain countries as do employees of other federal law enforcement agencies. To remedy this inequity, I along with Lou Corea (D-CA, introduced the bipartisan Danger Pay for U.S. Marshals Act. I am proud to have sponsored this bipartisan legislation which ensures, without requiring additional funding, that our Marshals are compensated fairly and earn the pay they rightly deserve while protecting Americans from violent criminals.          Signing USMCA: After more than a year waiting in limbo, the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement (USMCA) was signed this week by President Trump. USMCA is a big win for the American people, creating a more level playing field for workers, strengthening agricultural trade, and modernizing intellectual property protections. This agreement has the potential to create nearly 600,000 jobs and generate up to $235 billion in economic activity. USMCA opens new markets for our manufacturers and farmers, which will allow them to thrive. American agricultural exports are expected to increase by $2.2 billion under USMCA - with annual dairy exports predicted to rise by nearly $315 million. Further, the agreement is expected to create up to 76,000 new auto jobs, spur $34 billion in new investment in the auto industry, and add $23 billion in auto parts purchases each year. I am excited to have been a part of passing this historic agreement, and look forward to seeing the prosperity it is bound to bring to our country.   The President continues to keep his promise to the American people that he will fight for fairer trade deals for our nation. Not only did the President recently sign the Phase One Trade Deal in which China pledged to increase American imports by $200 billion over the next two years, but he also signed profitable deals with Japan and Taiwan.         Fentanyl & the Opioid Epidemic:  The opioid epidemic does not discriminate based on age, sex, race, or socioeconomic status. It is a plague that affects Americans in all regions of the country, including Virginia’s Sixth District. In 2016, the United States experienced an astonishing 60,000 deaths related to drug overdose, nearly two thirds of which involved opioids. That means that more than 91 Americans die from an opioid overdose each day, making it the leading cause of death for people under the age of 50. This crisis is being fueled in-part by a synthetic opioid known as fentanyl – a drug 80 to 100 times more powerful than morphine. In 2018 alone, more than 800 people died from fentanyl overdoses in Virginia.  I applaud my colleagues for voting to save lives this week by renewing the classification of fentanyl as a Schedule I narcotic. Through commonsense solutions like this and support for first responders and treatment programs, I am confident we can help our fellow Americans struggling with opioid abuse and end this insidious epidemic.  Fentanyl kills. The small dose pictured below is enough to be fatal.         Botetourt County's 250th Anniversary:  I took to the House Floor this week to recognize the 250th anniversary of Botetourt County.  Not only is our region filled with beautiful landscapes, but it is rich in history and culture. Whether it is to experience the countless outdoor recreation opportunities or to immerse themselves in an area with ties to great Americans like Thomas Jefferson and Lewis and Clark, visitors come from far and wide to experience the place where I and thousands of others are fortunate enough to live. May God continue to bless Botetourt County on its next 250 years.          Thank you for the opportunity to serve as your Congressman. If my office can ever be of assistance, please contact my Washington office at (202) 225-5431. For the latest updates from Washington, please follow my social media accounts: Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.                Washington D.C. It was great being back in the 11th District last week, where I traveled throughout communities and heard directly from folks at home about what we should be tackling in Congress. Hearing directly from my constituents about the issues facing the community helps me get it right in Washington.  This week, I had the opportunity to visit and walk through our local Lancaster county Home Depot. I appreciate Kyle teaching me about their paint department. Keep up the great work, Kyle!   Here is a fun video of my visit…  Click Here    During the district week, I had the opportunity to present Elizabeth Silbaugh Johnides, a constituent from Hanover, PA, with a copy of the Congressional Record which included my remarks about her outstanding service to the community in Hanover. To see my speak about her accomplishments on the House floor, click here.  I also had the opportunity to visit the Guthrie Memorial Library in Hanover with the new Mayor of Hanover SueAnn Whitman. At the library, I read a book to children about the importance of voting.    I toured the Elsner Engineering Works, a manufacturer of machines and equipment in Hanover, PA.   I finished the week at the PA Career Link Facility in York County to discuss the work they are doing to help veterans and individuals reenter the workforce.   Here is a video of my week in the district...  Click Here    The USMCA Is Signed Into Law!  On Wednesday, President Trump delivered on his promise to replace the outdated North American Free Trade Agreement (MAFTA) and signed into law the much-awaited United States-Mexico-Canada (USMCA) trade agreement.    The USMCA delivers on the promise President Trump made to replace the outdated North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. This deal marks a tremendous victory for Pennsylvania workers, farmers, manufacturers, and businesses. It has the potential to create nearly 600,000 jobs and generate up to $235 billion in economic activity.”   In Pennsylvania, trade with Canada and Mexico is essential. Over 42,000 jobs depend upon manufacturing exports to Canada and Mexico. The USMCA will provide businesses across the Commonwealth with new opportunities and will create new jobs with family-sustaining wages.     The signing of the USMCA into law means expanding and opening new market access for our Pennsylvania dairy, egg and poultry producers. New markets are welcome news for the nearly 7,000 family-owned and operated farms in PA-11. Our farmers in York and Lancaster Counties, who are national leaders in the production of milk and eggs, have only asked for a level playing field which to compete.   This modern trade deal brings our trade relationship with Canada and Mexico into the 21st century, protecting American intellectual property and ensuring strong, effective protections for innovators and creators. I congratulate the President for delivering on his promise, and I look forward to continuing to work with him to implement policies that benefit Pennsylvania and our nation.   The President and Vice President gave outstanding remarks at the signing of the bill, for those who may have not been able to watch, here is a link to watch the full bill signing.   Click Here     March For Life  On Friday, thousands of people from across America came to our nation’s capital to March for Life. I applaud President Trump for making history as becoming the first sitting president to attend the march. In his remarks, he reaffirmed his commitment to implementing pro-life and pro-family policies. Since 2017, the Trump Administration has established more conscience protections than ever before. While progress has been made, there is still more to accomplish.   It is always heartening to see so many young adults, families, and college groups come to peacefully demonstrate for the rights of the unborn. The fight to protect life from conception is one that involves all of us.  Click below to hear my remarks on the House floor about March For Life and also videos from the rally!   Click Here    Click Here    Click Here    WDAC Weekly Radio Appearance  Click Here     #NeverAgain  January 28th, 2020 marked the 75th year since the liberation of over 7,000 prisoners from the German Nazi Auschwitz camp. For nearly five years, these resilient individuals, including 700 children, saw their loved-ones murdered while they endured humiliation, suffering, and pain.  I cosponsored and voted in favor of the bipartisan Never Again Education Act (H.R. 943), which authorizes funding to be used to develop and nationally disseminate resources to promote understanding about how and why the Holocaust happened. The education materials will be developed by the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.   For more information on the Never Again Education Act click here.  WGAL discusses my vote on the bill below.  Click Here     Democrats’ Dangerous Attempt To Repeal The AUMF  This week I voted against the House Democrats’ dangerous attempts to tie the hands of the Commander – in – Chief by repealing the Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF). At a time when Congress should be projecting unity in the face of Iranian aggression, House Democrats have advanced a dangerous resolution that ultimately will accomplish nothing but division. By taking legal and necessary options off the table for the executive branch, this amendment emboldens our enemies and makes our nation less safe. The safety and security of the American people at home and abroad should be the central focus of our foreign policy. I strongly oppose this legislation. We must keep Americans safe. To read my full statement on this legislation, click here.   York County District Attorney’s Visits Washington  It was great to have York County District Attorney, Dave Sunday, in the office this week. He was in town for the National District Attorney Association 2020 Capital Conference. We discussed important criminal justice issues facing York County. I appreciate his office’s efforts to keep our community safe and look forward to continuing our discussion.     Honoring Rep. Mike Fitzpatrick  This week, Congress honored the life and service of Congressman Mike Fitzpatrick who lost his battle with cancer. He was a fierce advocate for Pennsylvania’s 8th district and he will be missed.  Click to Watch     Here’s Lloyd  Since I’ve taken office, I’ve held nearly 300 meetings with constituents and nearly 200 visits all across our district including schools, non-profit organizations and small businesses. Keep up to date by following my on Facebook, Twitter and visit “Here’s Lloyd” – a diary of all my visits across PA-11.     If you’d like to invite me to your school, business or community organization, please contact me at:  Request a meeting.      FOLLOW ME ON SOCIAL MEDIA    To stay up-to-date on my work in the district and Washington, be sure to follow me on Facebook and Twitter. You can also check out my YouTube page where there are 100+ videos, many of which are direct responses to your questions.    I'm also very proud of the help my office has been able to provide constituents. More than 4,400 individuals and families have been helped, and more than $4,964,699 has been returned to constituents.  If you need help with a federal agency, my office can help cut through Washington's red tape and bureaucracy. I encourage you to contact my district office at (717) 393-0667 and at (717) 969-6133 if you need assistance.  Sincerely,   Lloyd SmuckerMember of Congress                 Unsubscribe |       Open in web browser   Open in plain text

On January 8, the House passed H.R. 5065, the Prison to Proprietorship for Formerly Incarcerated Act, a bill I co-led and introduced with Rep. Hakeem Jeffries. This bill would provide small business counseling and training services to non-violent offenders. Some individuals who have paid their debt to society deserve a second chance at success, and this will prepare them to re-enter society and contribute to the workforce. The Prison to Proprietorship for Formerly Incarcerated Act follows another bill I co-led, the Patriotic Employer Protection Act, which passed the House in November, and later became law as part of the National Defense Authorization Act that the President signed into law in December. This legislation strengthens programs that enable employers to hire military reservists, and both bills speak to the effectiveness of bipartisan efforts that have the power to improve lives and strengthen our communities.  I’m committed to local investment and growth, which is why I co-sponsored H. Res. 815, Supporting Minor League Baseball. As you may have heard, Major League Baseball recently decided to eliminate 42 minor league clubs across the nation. This decision would affect six of Tennessee’s minor league teams. We’re fortunate to have the Tennessee Smokies nearby, and it would be a shame for towns from the East to West Coast to lose the local investment that minor league baseball provides.  At the end of last month, I was proud to introduce H.R. 5634, which would amend the Social Security Act so folks who are owed past-due Social Security benefits are paid first instead of their legal representatives. Since taking office, many of you have contacted me about your frustration with late Social Security payments, and I hope that this measure will enable those who have contacted me, as well as all Americans across the country who have worked their entire lives for Social Security benefits, to receive them in a timely manner.  As January closed, I joined my colleagues in remembering the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp by paying tribute to the survivors and victims of the Holocaust. I was honored to attend a Europe, Eurasia, Energy and the Environment Subcommittee meeting of the Foreign Affairs Committee where I heard Dr. Deborah E. Lipstadt, professor of Jewish history and Holocaust studies at Emory University, speak. My dad fought the Nazis in World War II, and I am extremely concerned at the recent rise in anti-Semitism. I will continue to support initiatives like this one that fight anti-Semitism and honor the victims of the Holocaust. I’m hosting a Town Hall meeting on Thursday, Feb. 20 from 6 to 7 p.m. at Jefferson City Hall, 112 City Center Drive. During the meeting, constituents will be able to ask questions and learn more about my legislative agenda. The event is free and open to the public.   Over the next month, my local team will staff Mobile Office Hours at three locations making it easier to get federal agency assistance and pass on your opinions. You do not need to make an appointment. Upcoming dates and locations are:   Tuesday, February 4 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at Philadelphia Public Library, 714 Thompson Street, Philadelphia Tuesday, February 11 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at Tazewell City Hall, 1830 Main Street, Tazewell Tuesday, February 25 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at Blaine City Hall, 220 Indian Ridge Road, Blaine  Have a question or concern? You’ll find my office contact info below. Please don’t hesitate to reach out.  Sincerely, Tim BurchettMember of Congress               Washington DC Office1122 Longworth HOBWashington, DC 20515(202) 225-5435 Knoxville Office800 Market Street, Suite 110Knoxville, TN 37902(865) 523-3772 Maryville Office331 Court StreetMaryville, TN 37804(865) 984-5464

subject: Senator King's Monthly e-Newsletter: January 2020 Recap
body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                January in Media  Press Releases King Statement After Senate Blocks New Witnesses     Maine Delegation Emphasizes Need to Hold China Accountable on American Lobster Commitment     King Supports Creation of Three-Digit Suicide Hotline     King Criticizes FDA for “Stark Reversal” on Planned Ban on Flavored E-Cigarettes     King Statement on the Passing of Galen Cole            Videos       Sharing my thoughts with News Center Maine on the importance of witness testimony. WATCH       Discussing the first day of the impeachment trial on CNN's New Day. WATCH         Emphasizing the need for de-escalation in rising tensions with Iran. WATCH       Laying out the debate on rules for the impeachment trial with Fox Bangor. WATCH      Scenes from Capitol Coffee Every Wednesday morning the Senate is in session from 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m., I am pleased to host “Capitol Coffee with Angus”, an opportunity for Maine people in the area to stop by my office, say hello, and talk about issues important to them.   Along with coffee, we are proud to provide homemade blueberry bread made with real Maine blueberries!                                                                                                      Simple Words, Profound Responsibility    See more of Senator King's photography on his Instagram   On the evening of a strange and somber day in early January, I walked slowly through the Capitol toward the House Chamber, retracing the steps of the seven representatives who had brought the articles of impeachment to the Senate a few hours earlier, a proceeding which has only happened twice before in our country’s history.  I hope the above photos give you a flavor of the quiet dignity of the place and the weight of the moment—the great rotunda shot from the shadow of Lincoln’s statue; the view across the rotunda back toward the Senate Chamber which had greeted that solemn procession; the old House Chamber, now Statuary Hall; the main door to the House, overseen by a bust of Lafayette; a downstairs corridor leading back under the rotunda; and as I walked out into the cold night air, the Capitol itself against a dark winter sky. I felt no joy on that day, but the burden of anticipation and a palpable sense of history. As the trial begins, each of us will takes a new oath “to do impartial justice”. Simple words, profound responsibility.   Scenes from Maine    Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.’s passion and eloquence lit a new path forward for our nation by reminding us of its promise to all; in doing so, he inspired generations of Americans to work towards that goal. His legacy lives on through each of us who choose to serve our communities and fight for equality.   On Martin Luther King Day, I spent the morning at the University of Maine with hundreds of Maine people who came together to celebrate Martin Luther King, Jr.’s legacy.    Maine has vast ocean resources, a commitment to sustainability, and an innovative workforce – all the tools we need to build a “blue economy”! I'm grateful for the work of New England Ocean Cluster to create jobs that support our economy and environment, and it was an honor to visit them earlier this month.     I stopped by the The Bangor Region YMCA earlier this month. The Bangor Y is a longtime pillar of the community, working to help young people address behavioral and mental health challenges, including substance use disorders.    Naturalization ceremonies are powerful examples of our nation’s principles: people who have worked to access the American dream swearing an oath to the Constitution. This month, I was honored to welcome 46 of our newest citizens in Portland; their contributions will enrich our nation.    Legislative Update    At the Council on Foreign Relations, Representative Mike Gallagher (R-Wisc.) and I discussed our work as co-chairs of the Cyberspace Solarium Commission.   Backed war powers resolution seeking to restore Congress's constitutional role in military actions. I announced my support and cosponsorship of a war powers resolution that would require a debate and vote in Congress before the United States initiates a war with Iran, while still allowing American personnel to defend themselves against Iranian threats. The resolution was introduced by Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.). Read more HERE. Pushed for IRS enforcement parity for all income levels. In a letter to Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Acting Director Russell Vought, I pushed to increase IRS funding to enhance tax compliance efforts and reduce targeting of low -income taxpayers. Read more HERE. Urged action to protect Maine's public housing tenants from radon exposure. I joined a bipartisan group of my colleagues requesting a meeting with the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to address the agency’s failure to protect tenants living in federally subsidized housing from the cancer-causing dangers of radon. Read more HERE. Fought against the SSA's proposed rule which would cause some individuals and families to reapply for eligibility for benefits more frequently without reason. This would place significant additional burden on individuals and families that are already stretched thin. Read more HERE.     Good News From Around Maine   Maine Federation of Farmers’ Markets (MFFM) has been awarded $160,111 for its Workplace to Market Project.  This funding was awarded through the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Farmers’ Market Promotion Program. The City of Portland has been awarded $750,000 for its Portland Landing Park Development Project, which aims to promote and enhance public access to Portland’s waterfront and quality outdoor recreation for residents and visitors. The Town of Kittery has received $500,000 from the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH). The federal funding will support the renovation and expansion of Rice Public Library. Midcoast Maine Community Action Program and Aroostook Micmac Council have received a total of $1,657,710 for their Head Start programs. Head Start programs are instrumental in ensuring that children cultivate new skills and receive educational opportunities that prepare them for a lifetime of success.    In the News   (AP) Bangor Daily News: Angus King says impeachment acquittal would shift power to White House Mainebiz: Delegation demands China's compliance on lobsters Washington Post: This is what a real Iran strategy would look like Maine Public: Sen. King Says Impeachment Trial ‘May Be One Of The Strangest Trials In American History’  Thanks for subscribing to my monthly newsletter! I would love to hear your ideas for how we can make Maine and our country a better place.      To contact me with a legislative question, concern or comment, please visit >. You can also call our toll free number in Maine at 1-800-432-1599.       To unsubscribe to this e-Newsletter click here.

Trump, effectively condoning the President’s crimes and the railroading of our Constitution. They did this in spite of disturbing new information that came to light last week from John Bolton, who wrote that the President ordered the shakedown of Ukraine two months before the July phone call with Ukraine's President Zelensky and the vast majority of Americans saying the Senate trial “should allow witnesses with firsthand knowledge to the impeachment charges to testify.”  Meanwhile, the Trump Administration continues with its ceaseless assault on women's rights and failure to respond to human suffering in the United States and around the world. That is why I am sharing this edition of Jackie's Reading Picks with you, a collection of articles, essays, and editorials that piqued my interest over the past week and that provide valuable insight and context for what is happening and what we can do to ensure that our core principles and values as Americans remain steadfast. I hope you will find them as informative, instructive, and, in some cases, as inspiring as I did.  Thank you for reading and all my best,                           As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District. If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above. You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.           A Dishonorable Senate By The Editorial Board, The New York Times The editorial board is a group of opinion journalists whose views are informed by expertise, research, debate and certain longstanding values. It is separate from the newsroom.                                                                      The vote also brings the nation face to face with the reality that the Senate has become nothing more than an arena for the most base and brutal — and stupid — power politics. Faced with credible evidence that a president was abusing his powers, it would not muster the institutional self-respect to even investigate. The week began with such promise, or at least with the possibility the Senate might not abdicate its constitutional duty. Leaks from John Bolton’s forthcoming book about his time in the White House appeared to confirm the core of the impeachment case against Mr. Trump: his extortion of Ukraine by explicitly conditioning hundreds of millions of dollars in military aid on the announcement of investigations into his political rival. For a moment, it seemed that enough Senate Republicans would come to their senses, listen to the overwhelming majority of Americans, and demand to hear testimony under oath from Mr. Bolton and maybe even other key witnesses to Mr. Trump’s Ukraine scheme. To read the complete editorial, click here.            Facebook is taking aim at coronavirus misinformation. Others should follow suit.                                                                     By The Editorial Board, The Washington Post THERE’S STILL no obvious right way for  Facebook announced this week that it would remove some posts, photographs and videos pushing misinformation about the epidemic. Some of these are conspiratorial, suggesting that the virus is part of a Chinese plot to build a bioweapon with stolen samples from a Canadian lab, or that U.S. government officials secretly patented a vaccine against the illness. Others related to treatment or prevention are more obviously dangerous: Vitamin C, for example, can’t guard against or cure coronavirus, and neither can oregano oil, cannabis, air purifiers or — scariest of all — bleach. It’s these particularly harmful nuggets of deception flagged by leading health authorities that Facebook is vowing to scrub from its platform, in a break with its preferred practice of merely reducing the distribution of offending content. It’s the right move amid an ongoing global crisis: Researchers have pointed to the damage done by widespread lies surrounding the Zika and Ebola viruses. The choice is also in keeping with the thinking that guides major technology companies as they moderate content: the higher the likelihood of real-world harm, the harsher the response. So while anti-vaccine screeds in general may get demoted and misleading advertisements banned, tall tales about a real-time public emergency are deleted entirely. To read the complete Washington Post editorial, click here.            New media outlet covering the intersection of women and politics launches as 2020 election kicks off By Sarah Ellison, The Washington Post  Then came the election of President Trump, the Women’s March, the start of the #MeToo movement. “It seems like there was a niche nonprofit newsroom for almost everything, and I wondered to myself why no one had created one at the intersection of women and politics,” Ramshaw said. She kept seeing a need. She continued in her role as editor in chief of the Texas Tribune but could not get the idea out of her head. In March last year, she sat down with Amanda Zamora, the Tribune’s chief audience officer and a veteran of the investigative nonprofit ProPublica, and presented her idea.AD “You could tell she was completely taken with this idea of a site that looked at the impact of politics and policy on women,” Zamora said. “Once she is set on something, you have no doubt that she’s going to make it happen, and I knew it was something I wanted to participate in.” To read the complete article, click here.            Her Uighur Parents Were Model Chinese Citizens. It Didn’t Matter. When Zulhumar Isaac’s parents disappeared amid a wave of detentions of ethnic minorities, she had to play a perilous game with the state to get them back. By Sarah A. Topol, The New York Times Magazine  Humar’s grandmother lived in a farming town that had once been outside Hami city, but as the city stretched out, subsuming the countryside, town and city merged. Over her grandmother’s lifetime, the Chinese state encouraged wave upon wave of migration of the ethnic Han majority to Xinjiang, which means “new frontier” in Mandarin, partly to dilute the Uighur presence while also cementing Communist Party rule in the natural-resource-rich region. By 1996, when Humar was 8, the proportion of Han in Xinjiang had risen to about 40 percent, up from 6.7 percent at the founding of the Communist Chinese state in 1949 — one of the largest demographic changes in China’s modern era. As a child, Humar was precocious and stubborn — “big headed,” the clan collectively called her. At the time, most Uighurs attended school in their own Turkic language, with Mandarin taught as a foreign language. As family lore has it, Humar herself demanded to attend a Mandarin school, so she could watch more channels on TV. Her parents, perhaps thinking more about their daughters’ future, endorsed the decision, enrolling Humar and her younger sister, Zumret. Before Humar’s first day of class, her parents sat her down to explain that she would be one of only a few Uighur students in her school. She would have to be especially careful about what she ate: There would be pork, which they, as mostly secular Muslims but Muslims nonetheless, could not eat. “Watch out,” h  er parents cautioned. “Pay attention to everything you put in your mouth.” Humar and Zumret would be the first in their extended family to attempt this integration, and their parents the first to navigate what it meant for their traditions. body: James M. Inhofe, US Senator for Oklahoma * INHOFE INFORMANT: Fighting for Life * * * In case you missed it, hundreds of pro-life Oklahomans joined tens of thousands of Americans to march for life last week. I was proud to stand with these marchers not only last week, but this week and every week. Read my entire op-ed on why we must continue to fight for life in the Oklahoman here [link 1] and below. [image = Inhofe in the Oklahoman: The war on the unborn: We must keep fighting* * If you watch the liberal news media today, you would think no one is advocating for the unborn or standing up for the right to life. Thank goodness the media has it wrong. Support in the United States for the pro-life position is strong. A recent Gallup poll showed 50% of Americans consider abortion morally wrong. For the first time since 2013, more Americans are pro-life (49%), rather than pro-abortion (46%). Other polling has found that the majority of Americans don't support taxpayer-funded abortion. By highlighting the value of all human life, we're making progress to end the abortion on demand culture. But the fight isn't nearly over. Liberal states are continuing to push for more and more extreme abortion laws. New York and Vermont have enacted laws that will allow abortion up to the moment of birth. Illinois passed a law making abortion a "fundamental right" and explicitly stating that unborn children do not have rights. It's heinous. The abortion-on-demand industry has no respect for the dignity of human life. Last year, authorities discovered more than 2,000 aborted fetal remains in the home of a deceased abortion doctor from Indiana. The evidence is clear: We must fight every day so abortion doesn't claim any more unborn babies. When you are pro-life, you believe every life is a gift from God that begins at conception -- no matter what. That means you believe in the value and future potential of every child. Sadly, not everyone sees that. Case in point: Over two-thirds of unborn babies diagnosed with Down syndrome are aborted in the United States. I introduced legislation to prohibit abortion based on a Down syndrome diagnosis. I also have cosponsored several key pro-life bills, including the Life at Conception Act, which recognizes that life begins at conception, and the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, which bans abortion after 20 weeks post-fertilization. On top of efforts in Congress, we have the most pro-life president in history. We have worked together to guarantee that federal tax dollars can't go toward abortion by protecting the Hyde Amendment and reinstating and expanding the Mexico City policy. We have also stripped abortion providers, like Planned Parenthood, of using federal Title X funding for abortions. And we're not done. Just this month, I joined more than 200 of my colleagues in urging the U.S. Supreme Court to reconsider Roe v. Wade. This would be a huge win for life. But, as we see with New York, Vermont and other states, when we make progress in Washington by standing for life, liberal states try to roll back those protections. That's why the work of Oklahomans for Life and events like Rose Day at the state Capitol are so important. Oklahoma is also consistently ranked as one of the top ten states most protective of life. This week alone, hundreds of pro-life Oklahomans will join tens of thousands of Americans who are marching for life. I'm proud to stand with these marchers this week and every week. We know that as we keep fighting for what is right, we will not be overcome. Rather, we will overcome evil with good by upholding and affirming the dignity and inherent worth of every human being. We will keep fighting. *Inhofe, R-Tulsa, is Oklahoma's senior U.S. senator.* I was glad to have so many of the Oklahomans marching for life stop by my office so we could talk about our shared values. *View some of the photos from their visit below:* [image = [image = [image = [image = ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] Office Locations: Washington, DC Office: 205 Russell Senate Office Building Washington, DC 20510 -3603 Main: (202) 224-4721 Fax: (202) 228-0380 Tulsa, OK Office: 1924 S. It was an honor to join President Trump at the signing ceremony for this historic trade agreement on behalf of the farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers who rely on a strong trade relationship with our neighbors to the north and south. The signing of this agreement signifies President Trump's kept promise to the American people: bringing NAFTA into the 21st Century and finally negotiating an agreement that benefits the United States, creates jobs, and expands access for our high-quality goods and services.   Learn more about how the USMCA will benefit Central Washington.    Time to Modernize in ESA   The Endangered Species Act was signed into law 47 years ago with the worthy goal of protecting and revitalizing endangered and threatened animals and wildlife. Unfortunately, the outdated law has proved to be a staggering failure for the species it was intended to aid, with only a 3% recovery rate.     Click here to watch my remarks on the House floor.  I hosted a Special Order with my colleagues of the Western Caucus to discuss our ongoing effort to strengthen and modernize the Endangered Species Act by creating a comprehensive approach to advance species recovery. By using the best available science, considering all conservation measures, streamlining processes for listing decisions, and empowering state and local efforts to contribute to species recovery, we can fulfill the true intent of the ESA.  Click here to learn more about ESA Modernization.   Angels in Adoption  A big congratulations to Jake and Angie Moore of Yakima for being named Central Washington's Angels in Adoption for 2019! The Moore's have opened their hearts and their home to several foster children in the Yakima Valley, recently finalizing the adoption of their daughter and welcoming a 2-year-old foster son. Thank you, Jake and Angie, for all you do to advocate for foster care and adoption and for becoming a family for these children who need a home.   Promoting Services for Domestic Violence Survivors  Did you know the Yakima Police Department responds to 10-12 domestic violence cases per day? I toured the YWCA Yakima to learn about the programs and services they offer victims of domestic violence throughout the Yakima Valley. From the emergency shelter and housing services to prevention and outreach, the staff at the YWCA is working to curb this terrifying statistic and provide support for families in need.  The Next Generation  Last week, I had the pleasure of visiting Mr. Fickel's exceptional 6th grade class at Harrison Middle School in Sunnyside - my old stomping grounds! I had the opportunity to speak with students about my role as their Representative in Congress, and I was impressed by their thoughtful questions about civics and current events. It's important to teach the next generation about our government in order to have an informed public, and I am proud to be a part of that.   To stay current on the work I am doing around the District and in Washington D.C., I encourage you to follow me  on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and to read updates on my website.  It is an honor and a privilege to represent you in Congress. On Wednesday, President Trump signed the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) into law. Our businesses (both small and large), workers, and economy will all benefit from this trade deal. Estimates say it will add $68 billion to our economy and create over 170,000 new American jobs. In Ohio alone, over 100,000 jobs depend on exports to Mexico and Canada. Make no mistake, this is big; this trade agreement will have tremendous benefits for those I represent. Just like Phase One of the China trade deal, this is another economic promise that President Trump has made good on. It was way past time for the outdated NAFTA agreement to be put in the shredder and to stand up for the American worker...the USMCA does that.     Visit to Pennex Aluminum Plant   One of my stops earlier today was in Leetonia at Pennex Aluminum. The company is an industry leader in the casting, extruding, and fabricating of aluminum products. While there, I visited and met with employees, toured the plant and learned about their recent 100,000 sq. ft. expansion in Columbiana County. It’s encouraging to see all of the local growth in the manufacturing industries. Afterwards, I headed down to Jefferson County for some more meetings and stops at small businesses.      NO to Proposed Jefferson County Landfill Like many of you in Jefferson County, I’ve been following the developments surrounding the old Crossridge Landfill. I’ve also heard from many of you directly regarding the situation, and I appreciate hearing your views on this important issue. Citizens are organizing against it, and know this…I stand with YOU for the future of Jefferson County. I’ve spoken with many local officials about this landfill issue, and we are all in agreement. Jefferson County is making very positive progress on several fronts, and now is not the time to lose this positive momentum. I have already conveyed my concerns about the landfill to officials at the Ohio EPA, and I plan on meeting with the Director of the Ohio EPA about this soon - I will be voicing OUR opposition. The first landfill on the site, which closed in 2016, was a total environmental disaster. We don’t need or want another dump site where other states can dump their garbage; they should find a way to handle their garbage in their own back yard.     Navigable Waters Protection Rule Announcement For years, businesses, farmers, energy developers, and landowners have asked the federal government to give them certainty and clarity when it comes to how federal clean water regulations affect the permitting process. The new Navigable Waters Protection Rule announced on January 24 by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will provide exactly that - better certainty and clarity for the permitting process while protecting our water in Ohio and across the country. The Obama-era “Waters of the United States” rule - a serious case of regulatory overreach where Washington bureaucrats took over local decision making - is now gone. Again and again, I spoke up against this burdensome, intrusive rule imposed by the Obama Administration’s EPA. Right after I sent out last week’s eNewsletter, I discussed this new rule at an EPA and Army Corps of Engineers roundtable in Columbus. We talked about how this new rule right sizes the role of the federal government, and does not overstep its boundaries nor encroach on states’ rights. For instance, the Ohio EPA already does a great job, because they live and work here in Ohio where they depend on the cleanliness of our water resources; they want their families and neighbors to have clean water, and they know the area better than someone sitting behind a desk in Washington. I look forward to working with the EPA and the Army Corps of Engineers to successfully implement this new rule in the days and years to come.    Thank you again for subscribing to my weekly District Download. If you have something on your mind, you can contact me at one of the numbers below, or send me an email by clicking on this link here to contact me. It is my pleasure to serve you, and I hope to see you around Eastern and Southeastern Ohio soon.         Stay up to date with the latest news by following me on Social Media! Invest $105 billion to increase viable transit options; Invest $55 billion to expand rail networks; Invest $30 billion for modern airports; Invest $50.5 billion for clean water and wastewater infrastructure; Invest $10 billion for water infrastructure; Invest $19.7 billion for harbors, ports and channels; Invest $2.7 billion to restore brownfields; Invest $21.4 billion to protect drinking water; Invest $38.3 billion in clean energy; Invest $86 billion to expand broadband and communications; Invest $12 billion for public safety communications; and Create an estimated 10 million jobs!  This plan is the centerpiece of our For the People Agenda and will work to both address the climate crisis and make our infrastructure smarter, safer and long-lasting. While that’s been happening, here’s what else I’ve been up to:          Celebrating Chiropractor Day       I had the pleasure of meeting with Dr. Perman this week on Chiropractor’s Day! We had a great discussion on the importance of chiropractic work in the field of medicine, and I am excited to see how the practice develops in the future of this country.     Remembering Terry DeCarlo         On Tuesday, we lost a pillar of the Orlando community & a dedicated champion of LGBT rights. Although he will be greatly missed, we take comfort in knowing his work in the aftermath of the Pulse tragedy left a mark in the lives of dozens of families. Rest In Peace, Terry DeCarlo.     Regulating Cell-based Meat         I was also able to introduce the Cell-Cultured Meat Bill with Congressman Dusty Johnson, which aims to provide transparency and information about alternative meat products as they start to become more available to consumers.     Recognizing Tom Flores        With the Super Bowl around the corner in Miami, it is my distinct honor to present a resolution with Congressman Jim Costa which urges that Tom Flores, the first Hispanic player in the NFL, be inducted in the Pro Football Hall of Fame.             Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in Congress! I was proud to co-lead this legislation with Rep. Carolyn Maloney (NY-12), and managed its passage on the Floor on Monday. The bill would amplify the work of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, leveraging a combination of public and private funds to develop and disseminate high-quality Holocaust education resources, which can be adopted by local schools and included in their curriculum. The bill has the support of more than 1,800 Holocaust survivors from 38 states, as well as 350 organizations from across the country. On Monday, the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, the House reaffirmed its commitment to remembrance by passing this bill to ensure the next generation of students understand the dangers of rising anti-Semitism and recognize that it must never be forgotten. As we continue to condemn horrific acts of anti-Semitism across the world, we must also take proactive measures to educate and provide states and schools with the resources necessary to incorporate Holocaust education into their classrooms, ensuring that all students understand the evils of Holocaust and its impact. I am honored to co-lead this important legislation, and I applaud my colleagues in the House for its bipartisan passage. Watch my opening remarks on the House Floor in support of this legislation here and above, and my closing remarks here.  Statement on President Trump Signing USMCA Into Law    This week, I proudly attended the signing of the USMCA trade agreement into law by President Trump. This is a significant victory for the North Country, and I am thrilled that the USMCA has been signed into law. This agreement will expand our markets for American-made goods with two vital trading partners, boosting our North Country economy. It also provides stability for our agriculture industry by increasing access to those markets. I have been an outspoken supporter of this important agreement from the beginning, and I will continue to work on behalf of North Country farmers, small businesses, manufacturers, and hardworking families to deliver crucial results like these. Read more here.  Advocating for Rural Broadband for the North Country   Earlier this month, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) released a draft proposal for their new Rural Digital Opportunity Fund, which rendered all of New York ineligible for the $16 billion allocated in Phase I of the plan to expand high-speed broadband access. I called the Chairman of the FCC directly and sent a bipartisan letter with the New York delegation asking them to reverse this decision, and to reiterate the need for underserved areas in the North Country to be included in the funding. This week, FCC Chairman Pai sent a letter back to me  stating that the proposal will be revised and areas of New York will be considered for Phase I eligibility under the general criteria. Expanding access to high-speed broadband is critical to the economic well-being of our region.  The FCC reversing their decision to categorically exclude New York is an important step in the right direction, as this will open the door to much needed investment in the areas of North Country that still lack broadband connectivity. However, the FCC’s treatment of areas without high-speed access despite some state investment will be central to the Rural Digital Opportunity Fund fulfilling its goal of truly closing the digital divide. I will to continue to work closely with the FCC throughout the development of this important initiative to expand rural broadband access in the North Country. Read more here.   Testifying Before Ways & Means Committee on Bipartisan Paid Leave Proposal    This week, I testified before the House Ways & Means Committee in support of H.R. 5296, the Advancing Support for Working Families Act, legislation I am leading with Rep. Colin Allred (D-TX). This legislation will help working families cover the cost of parental leave, infant care, and other expenses that occur with birth or adoption of a new child by advancing up to $5,000 of their Child Tax Credit. It is the only bipartisan and bicameral plan to help new parents access upfront financial assistance – and does it without raising taxes or creating new federal mandates. Developing solutions to help new parents and working families thrive in this modern workforce is necessary for the continued economic success of our nation and the well-being of the next generation of Americans. I will always advocate on behalf of hardworking North Country families to bring them tangible benefits and enhanced paid leave options as I continue to lead this effort through the House. Watch my full testimony here and above.   Cosponsoring Bill Protecting Voter Registration Systems Against Foreign Hacking   This week, I became an original cosponsor of the Protect American Voters Act, legislation to provide states with more adequate resources to secure their current and future election systems. This bill updates the Help America Vote Act of 2002 by directing the Election Assistance Commission to issue guidelines for “non-voting” election equipment, including electronic pollbooks, election night reporting systems, online voter registration systems, and other equipment. It also establishes the first-ever “Election Cyber Assistance Unit” to connect local and state election officials with leading election administration and cybersecurity experts from across the country. Securing our elections includes prioritizing the protection of voter’s personal information, which has been at risk to foreign hacking for too long. I am proud to cosponsor this bill to ensure election equipment is utilized in a way that protects voter information, and that states are provided with resources and guidance to secure their individual election systems. I am a staunch advocate for measures to protect American elections from any foreign interference, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to advance this effort. Read more here.  Announcing USDA Primary Agriculture Disaster Designation for the North Country   This week, I announced a USDA Primary Agricultural Disaster designation for all twelve counties in New York’s 21st Congressional District. This designation comes after excessive rain and weather events caused massive losses during the 2019 crop year. This designation makes farm operators eligible to be considered for certain assistance from the Farm Service Agency (FSA), including emergency loans. Farmers in these counties have 8 months from the date of this declaration to apply for emergency loans, and they are encouraged to act as soon as possible. The weather events this past spring, including excessive flooding in many areas, took a toll on farmers across upstate New York. I am glad USDA has made this designation and will be offering aid to producers, who are vital to the North Country. I encourage any farmers who have questions about this application process to reach out to my offices directly. Read more here.  As always, thank you for subscribing to my weekly updates!    Sincerely,    Elise StefanikMember of Congress             Social Media Corner:         ___________________  Featured Read:  Press Republican -  Officials praise signing of USMCA  President Donald Trump's signing of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement into law drew praise from organizations and North Country officials.  Congresswoman Elise Stefanik (R-Schuylerville) lauded ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement's (NAFTA) replacement as a significant victory for the region.  "This agreement will expand our markets for American-made goods with two vital trading partners, boosting our North Country economy," she said in a statement.  "It also provides stability for our agriculture industry by increasing access to those markets.  I am proud to have been an outspoken supporter of this important agreement from the beginning, and I will continue to work on behalf of North Country farmers, small businesses, manufacturers and hardworking families to deliver crucial results like these."  North Country Chamber of Commerce President Garry Douglas said nothing is more important to the area's economy than its cross-border economic partnership with Canada.  "With the enactment of the enabling legislation for USMCA, we can expect the continued benefits that will flow from a renewed and predictable economic relationship," he said in a statement.  "The North Country, more than any other area of the U.S., has made itself a uniquely supportive environment for Canadian-based manufacturing in the U.S. market and for cross-border supply chains."  Douglas said the North Country's transportation equipment and aerospace cluster is a prime example, with 50 companies employing more than 9,000 people.  New York Farm Bureau President David Fisher said nearly half of the state's agricultural exports go to the country's North American neighbors.  "Thanks to the president’s signature on USMCA, goods will continue to cross borders to benefit our state’s farms and rural economy," he continued.  "The agreement provides certainty to farmers as well as opens the door to additional market opportunities, most notably for our dairy farms."  Douglas and Fisher thanked Stefanik for her support of the agreement's passage.  "Congresswoman Stefanik has been in the forefront of passage of the USMCA that is essential to balance and strengthen the capability of North America’s competitiveness and enhancing U.S.-Canada economic vitality," Canadian/American Border Trade Alliance President/CEO Jim Phillips said.  Trump, former Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau signed the USMCA on Nov. 30, 2018.  The Mexican Senate ratified the agreement in June, and in December voted overwhelmingly to accept changes made as a result of negotiations between House Democrats and the White House. _________________  Constituent Services  Please contact my Glens Falls office at (518) 743-0964 if you would like help with:   Federal agencies. Purchasing U.S. flags. Military Academy Nominations. Tours and tickets for your visit to Washington, D.C. Internships. And other resources.  Glens Falls Office  5 Warren Street, Suite 4  Glens Falls, NY 12801  _________________  Weekly Legislative Recap  Below find a list of legislation that the House of Representatives voted on this week.  H.R.5671 - Merchant Mariners of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2020 (Passed via Voice Vote)  S.153 - Supporting Veterans in STEM Careers Act (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.943 - Never Again Education Act (Passed 393-5; I voted Yes)  H.R.4704 - Advancing Research to Prevent Suicide Act (Passed 385-8; I voted Yes)  H.R.5338 - Global Hope Act of 2019 (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.Res.752 - Supporting the rights of the people of Iran to free expression, condemning the Iranian regime for its crackdown on legitimate protests, and for other purposes (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.2153 - Keeping Girls in School Act (Passed via Voice Vote)  H.R.4331 - Tibetan Policy and Support Act of 2019 (Passed 392-22; I voted Yes)  H.R.3621 - Student Borrower Credit Improvement Act (Passed 221-189; I voted No)  S.3201 - Temporary Reauthorization and Study of the Emergency Scheduling of Fentanyl Analogues Act (Passed 32-88; I voted Yes)                   Washington, DC  318 Cannon H.O.B.Washington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4611Fax: (202) 226-0621 Glens Falls 5 Warren Street, Suite 4Glens Falls, NY 12801Phone: (518) 743-0964Fax: (518) 743-1391 Watertown88 Public SquareSuite AWatertown, NY 13601Phone: (315) 782-3150Fax: (315) 782-1291 Plattsburgh Office 137 Margaret StreetSuite 100Plattsburgh, NY 12901Phone: (518) 561-2324Fax: (518) 561-2408          Unsubscribe - Privacy

Select "Always display images" or  Click here to open in browser.                       Investing in America’s Infrastructure             Rebuilding America’s Infrastructure  Democrats believe we must act to rebuild America’s infrastructure, creating good-paying jobs and addressing the climate crisis in the process with infrastructure that is smarter, safer and made to last.  That is why this week, we unveiled our Moving Forward framework to create an estimated 10 million jobs by investing $760 billion over five years in the nation’s roads, bridges, transit systems, railways, airports, ports, inland waterways, wastewater and drinking water systems, brownfields and broadband.     Investing in our infrastructure means investing in American workers and manufacturing.  Our framework calls for supporting U.S. industries, including steel and manufacturing, through strong Buy America protections.  It would also create family-wage jobs with Davis-Bacon and other strong worker protections.  By putting people to work on transformative projects in urban and rural communities across the country, we can support jobs that can’t be exported.           The Moving Forward framework also includes a strong focus on reducing carbon pollution, strengthening energy efficiency and advancing renewable energy systems – taking an important step in combating the climate crisis while also strengthening our economy, creating good-paying clean energy sector jobs and providing much-needed relief to American families on their energy bills.     Democrats are moving forward with our plan because the cost of inaction is too great for our communities.  Now, it’s time for President Trump to return to the bipartisan conversation on how to fund rebuilding America’s infrastructure that he stormed out of last year.                Keeping Americans Safe As Members of Congress, our first responsibility is to keep the American people safe.  Three weeks ago, this House honored that duty by passing the War Powers Resolution to limit the President's military actions regarding Iran.      Members of Congress continue to have serious concerns about the President's decision to engage in hostilities against Iran and about his lack of strategy moving forward.  That is why, this week, the House took additional steps to protect American lives and values by passing two strong pieces of legislation, Congresswoman Barbara Lee's legislation to repeal the 2002 Iraq Authorization for Use of Military Force, AUMF, and Congressman Ro Khanna's legislation to prohibit funding for military action against Iran, not authorized by Congress. I am thankful for these Bay Area Members’ longstanding leadership to protect American lives.   Our brave service men and women, and their families, and all Americans deserve smart, strong and strategic action, not the Administration's reckless and rash policies.                Administration Reveals Illegal Medicaid Block Grant Scheme The Trump Administration’s Medicaid block grant guidance is the latest example of President’s obsession with taking away Americans’ health care by any and all means.  After being stopped in the Congress from repealing the health care law and destroying the lifeline of Medicaid, the Administration has decided to ignore the law and steal lifesaving health care from seniors and families anyway.  The Administration’s plan for states to cap and slash Medicaid will have ruinous consequences for rural hospitals, for families seeking opioid addiction treatment for their loved ones and for middle-class seniors with long-term care needs. It would invite states to push Medicaid recipients off of lifesaving medicines, impose unaffordable premiums to maintain coverage and leave more vulnerable families exposed to catastrophic medical bills. At every turn, the Administration is working to undermine protections for people with pre-existing conditions and to steal the promise of affordable, dependable health care. In the Congress and in the courts, Democrats will fight back against the Administration’s illegal block grant scheme to dismantle the health care of seniors and families.                 A constituent contacted my office requesting help expediting her Social Security Administration disability benefits that had been awarded to her some time ago. My office was successful in requesting expedition of the process, and my constituent received her back pay in a timely manner. Caseworkers in my San Francisco office work to address any problems or concerns you may have with a federal government agency. To submit a Casework Authorization Form, please visit my website.       Please feel free to forward this information to your family and friends. To learn more about these efforts, express your views, or sign up for email updates, please visit my website.          best regards,           This mailing was prepared, published and mailed at taxpayer expense Unsubscribe                WASHINGTON, DC 1236 Longworth HOBWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-4965 DISTRICT OFFICE 90 7th Street, Suite 2-800San Francisco, CA 94103Phone: (415) 556-4862                      /***** SMARTPHONE STYLING RULES *****/ @media only screen and (max-width: 497px) { *[class*="container"] { width:100% !important; table-layout:auto !important;} }   p { margin-bottom:1em; }

Ilhan Omar‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌           JANUARY 2020: IN THE DISTRICT, NO BAN ACT, & PEOPLE'S HOUSING PLATFORM  Dear Friend,  When I first arrived in the US from a refugee camp with no permanent housing, I turned to my father and said, “This is not the America you told us about.” He smiled and calmly said, “Hush Child. We will get to that America.” More than two decades later, I am still hopeful for an America where housing is treated as a human right.  This week, I joined my colleagues in the Congressional Progressive Caucus to launch a groundbreaking initiative to address the housing crisis and make housing a human right. I also continued to fight against the xenophobic Muslim Ban and challenged an outdated and dangerous law that gives the executive branch extreme power to target our immigrant communities. Last week I was home in Minneapolis hosting events on the housing and opioid crises our communities are facing in the 5th and around the country.   Despite the many systemic challenges we are facing in the district and around the country, I know that the struggles of today will bring us closer to the America of our dreams.  Thank you for being an engaged constituent. I look forward to hearing from you!  In service,    Ilhan Omar Member of Congress    UPCOMING EVENTS Join us for a Community Conversation with Congresswoman Omar on Combating Hate on Thursday, February 20 from 6:30-8:00 PM CST. RSVP on Eventbrite using this link.  For all updates and upcoming events visit our website here. All events are free and open to the public.    Back in the District School Visit Being home means that I can do what I love most: visiting local schools, like Sandburg Middle School. I am always inspired by listening to our youth’s visions for a future where everyone is able to be their full self. You're never too young to engage in our democracy! Opioid Roundtable I hosted a vital discussion with the Cedar-Riverside community on the opioid crisis. Addressing this pressing problem requires a public health approach, which means we should not be criminalizing those struggling with addiction. I was grateful for the community wisdom on how we can heal our communities together. Town Hall I was joined by some of my brilliant partners in the district working to ensure that everyone in this country is granted their basic human right to safe and affordable housing. Guaranteeing Homes for All is a core part of addressing the climate crisis and preventing displacement, and we need bold policies to address the scale of the crisis we face.      No Ban Act On the third anniversary of the hateful Muslim Ban, I joined colleagues from the House and Senate to remind the President that we will not tolerate religious bigotry in this country. Here in the United States, the values that unite us are upholding civil liberties and ensuring basic human rights for all. We must remember that the fight to place the Muslim Ban in the dustbin of history does not end with its repeal. The stains of this policy and others like it will remain if we don’t collectively work to change hearts and minds so that we can truly treat each other as neighbors.     The People's Housing Platform This week, along with other members of the Congressional Progressive Caucus and housing justice advocates, we launched the People’s Housing Platform, which includes my Homes For All legislation. This groundbreaking, progressive housing framework declares what we know to be true: housing is a fundamental human right, and it is inextricably tied to the struggles for climate and racial justice.      Neighbors Not Enemies Act I also introduced the Neighbors Not Enemies Act, which fully repeals the Alien Enemies Act of 1798. This outdated and dangerous law permits the President extreme executive powers to target an entire group of foreign nationals.  It is an offense to our values as a nation, which should stand as a refuge for those fleeing violence and persecution and is a perfect example of outdated immigration laws that are being exploited and abused by this Administration. As the President seeks to expand the Muslim Ban, we must close policy loopholes that he can exploit to cause harm to our neighbors, our country and the values that we hold dear.          Stay Updated with the Office of Representative Ilhan Omar   Please do not respond to this e-mail. Contact the Office    SUBSCRIBE SERVICES  Unsubscribe  |  Privacy

 more--a year in review from Congresswoman Clarke
